DOC.HEAD: U.N. Human Rights Envoy Arrives In Iran For Probe
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. delegation arrived in Tehran Sunday to begin the first outside investigation into alleged human rights abuses since the 1979 Islamic revolution. The delegation's trip marks a significant breakthrough for human rights campaigners who have long accused Iran of abuses. Thousands of people reportedly have been executed since 1979. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the U.N. team was scheduled to meet several senior Iranian officials but did not identify them. The mission is led by Reynaldo Galindo Pohl, the U.N. Human Rights Commission's special envoy and an international law expert from El Salvador. The U.N. investigation comes amid efforts by President Hashemi Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, to liberalize society after a decade of rigid Moslem fundamentalism. Rafsanjani was elected July 28. He since has dumped prominent radicals from senior government posts as part of his effort to renew ties with the West and attract badly needed foreign investment to revitalize Iran's moribund economy. Shortly after the U.N. team arrived, Tehran Radio reported that the chief of Iran's judiciary, Ayatollah Mohammad Yazdi, told a meeting of prison directors in Tehran that all inmates must be treated ``with respect and in accordance to Islamic law.'' It is not known how many people are behind bars in Iran. Dissident groups claim thousands of political prisoners are held without trial, languishing in appalling conditions and subjected to torture. Tehran invited Galindo Pohl to visit Iran in November, ending a longtime policy of barring foreign observers from checking its human rights practices. The invitation was extended after Galindo Pohl produced an interim report, based mainly on evidence from Iranian dissidents, that abuses continued after Iran's revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, died June 3. That report cited 1,700 people ``possibly executed'' and said prisoners were flogged, whipped on the soles of their feet with barbed wire, burned with cigarettes, sexually abused, locked up in heated boxes and subjected to mock executions. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, said in its 1989 report that Iran executed more than 1,200 political prisoners between July 1988 and December 1988. The English language Tehran Times daily, which usually reflects Rafsanjani's thinking, said Jan. 17 that the U.N. mission's visit was ``the best way to neutralize baseless propaganda by the Western media and enemies of the Islamic revolution.'' Galindo Pohl will submit a report on his findings to the Human Rights Commission's annual six-week session in Geneva that is to begin Jan. 29. Nearly 1,000 people reportedly have been executed since December 1988. Iran responded to criticism of those executions by saying that nearly all involved drug traffickers convicted by Islamic courts. Iranian opposition groups said many were political prisoners, however.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Decertifies Controller in Runway Collision
DOC.TEXT: The air traffic controller who was in charge of two planes involved in a fatal runway crash last week was stripped of his certification, a federal investigator said Sunday. The controller failed to warn the pilot of an Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 that had just landed that there was a smaller plane on the runway in front of him, said the official from the National Transportation Safety Board. The pilot of the smaller plane, a twin-engine Beechcraft King Air, was killed in the accident Thursday night at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. The co-pilot of the Beechcraft was slightly injured, but nobody aboard the airliner was hurt. The pilot of the Eastern plane, which carried 141 passengers, spotted the smaller plane too late and tried to veer away, but the airliner's right wing struck the smaller plane's cockpit. Safety board investigators were told the FAA had decertified the controller due to an error made because procedures were not followed, the NTSB said in a news release Sunday under the name of chief investigator Bob MacIntosh. MacIntosh refused to answer questions. The controller, whose name was withheld, may apply for retraining and recertification, but won't be allowed to direct air traffic without certification. The controller was hired by the FAA in 1982 and has worked in the Atlanta tower since October 1988, the NTSB said. He took his post about four minutes before the accident. NTSB investigators said Saturday the pilot of Eastern Flight 111 from New York wasn't warned of the smaller plane on the runway ahead of him, as is required. During a 2{-hour interview with NTSB investigators Sunday, the controller acknowledged it was his responsibility to ensure the runway was clear before allowing another plane to land, the NTSB statement said. ``He stated that he thought that the King Air had cleared the runway and was surprised that it had not,'' the statement said. ``However, he did not actually observe the King Air clear the runway. He could not explain why he did not offer traffic information to Eastern 111 about the King Air flight as required by air traffic control procedures.'' The controller also ``indicated that he was distracted'' by two other aircraft, one that had just landed and another on landing approach that had reported a possible hydraulic problem, the statement said. The Eastern pilot, 23-year veteran Ralph Orlando, blamed the crash on the controller. ``We should have been advised, at a minimum, that there was a small plane and that it might not be cleared,'' Orlando said. Apparently no one in the tower saw the collision, MacIntosh said. The pilot who was killed, Eric Thomas, 30, worked for Atlanta-based Epps Air Service.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Wealth Overstated, Investigators Say
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are concluding the Bush administration exaggerated ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega's wealth, The Miami Herald reported Sunday. Many of the assets cited by the administration as evidence of Noriega's fortune belonged to Panama's defense forces or are registered to businessmen close to him, according to documents emerging from Panamanian government offices in the aftermath of the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion. A case in point, the Herald said, was the U.S. State Department allegation that Noriega owned a Boeing 727 jet, three Lear jets and three luxury boats named Macho I, Macho II and Macho III. Documents found in recent weeks suggest that none of those planes and boats may be traceable to Noreiga, unidentified officials of the U.S.-installed Panamanian government with access to the seized records told the newspaper. That could complicate efforts by prosecutors to portray Noriega as an immensely wealthy man in the former general's upcoming federsal trial on drug charges in Miami. Noriega is accused of making millions in protection payments from Colombian drug traffickers who used Panama to fly drugs to the United States. The Boeing 727, purchased in 1983 for $2.2 million,. was first acquired by the state-run Air Panama airline and later transferred to Panama's defense forces, air traffic authorities said. Of the three executive jets, a Lear 35 that was regularly used by Noriega was rented by Panama's defense forces to a Miami company for $230,000 a month, officials said. A second Lear jet appears to be partly owned by Carlos Duque, a businessman-poltician who made millions from his association with the former dictator. Officials said they don't know of a third Lear jet used by Noriega. The Macho I and Macho II were owned by Carlos Wittgreen, another businessman who profited greatly from his friendship with Noriega, documents show. No records on the third boat have been found. Noriega loyalists said the general used the military aircraft in his capacity as defense forces commander. The boats were simply lent to him by his best friends, they said. ``All these properties cited by the U.S. government exist but were not his,'' said Mario Rognoni, a former commerce minister with the Noriega regime. ``It's like saying that Camp David belongs to (President) Bush.'' Officials of the new civilian government counter that there is widespread evidence that Noriega amassed a significant fortune after taking over the defense forces in 1983. But officials privately concede that the U.S. government may have liberally mixed fact with fiction in its efforts to convince the world about Noriega's crimes, the Herald said. The State Department's contention that Noriega's personal wealth was at least $200 to $300 million will be hard to prove, investigators said.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis See Hopeful Signs for Themselves in Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd in b0286 of Jan. 18 to UPDATE with Peres in Czechoslovakia.
DOC.TEXT: The anti-communist revolutions in Eastern Europe have yielded a bonanza for Israel in renewed diplomatic ties and the Israelis hope it also means the end of training and weapons support for Arab radicals. New openings toward Israel by countries that once firmly backed the Arab cause ends a two-decade Soviet-bloc boycott of the Jewish state imposed by Moscow after the 1967 Middle East war. On Sunday, Vice Premier Shimon Peres became the highest ranking Israeli since 1967 to visit Czechoslovakia. ``We are now opening a new page in our relations with Eastern Europe,'' said Yossi Ben-Aharon, a top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Foreign Minister Gyula Horn of Hungary, who recently visited Jerusalem, described the changes as ``irreversible.'' ``The old order cannot be restored,'' the Jerusalem Post quoted him as saying in an interview. But it remains unclear whether the renewal of ties will translate into long-term diplomatic support for Israel in the Middle East conflict. Horn indicated Hungary was more interested in flourishing economic ties than the Middle East conflict. However, he said he supported an international Middle East peace conference, a proposal accepted by the Arabs but staunchly rejected by Shamir. ``The Eastern Europe of today is not as pro-Palestinian as before, but if Israel continues its hard line toward the Palestinians, we cannot expect to win the support of these countries,'' said Moshe Zimmermann, a historian at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Palestinian analysts, meanwhile, acknowledged the Palestine Liberation Organization suffered a diplomatic setback in Eastern Europe because of its association with the overthrown communist dictators. They said the PLO faced an uphill struggle to win the support of the new leadership. ``The atmosphere is, to a certain extent, hostile to the Palestinians,'' said Ghassan Katib, a prominent Palestinian communist and West Bank university lecturer. ``We must establish a dialogue with the these new forces.'' Anti-Arab sentiment is especially strong in Romania where Arabs were identified in revolutionary quarters as fighting in the ranks of the hated Securitate secret police who sought to crush the popular uprising against dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. In the meantime, the new Eastern European leaders are knocking on Israel's door to renew ties cut in 1967. In September, Hungary became the first. Poland and Czechoslovakia are expected to follow this spring. Romania never severed ties, although it supported and trained Arab guerrillas. Israel never had relations with East Germany, but a senior Israeli official said such ties were expected if, as seems likely, the East Germans drop their refusal to accept moral responsibility for the Holocaust. In light of East Germany's economic problems, Israel would be satisfied with a token payment of reparations, the official said. Eastern European leaders are mainly driven by the need to rescue their crippled economies, and Israel, a close ally of the United States, is seen as an important mediator. ``They believe Israel can pave the way for improved economic relations with the Western world,'' said Mark Heller, an analyst at Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. But Israel is also seen as an economic partner in its own right. Israeli exports to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union jumped to $100 million last year, up 70 percent from 1988. The new Eastern European leaders, whose political survival depends in part on their ability to end food shortages at home, are especially interested in Israel's agricultural know-how. In December, the government-owned Israeli company Agridev signed a cooperation agreement with Bulgaria under which Israel will provide experts and equipment to run Bulgarian farms. A similar agreement is expected to be signed with Poland. ``In the past year, many doors have been opened, due to the changes in the political situation and the desire to supply enough food,'' said Amram Olmert, managing director of Agridev. In addition to the diplomatic and economic windfalls, Israeli officials cite a third beneficial development: an end to state sponsorship of Palestinian terror squads. In the past, the PLO and other Palestinian groups maintained close ties with Eastern Europe, especially Romania, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, which trained and armed hundreds of Palestinian guerrillas, according to Israeli intelligence sources. ``These countries provided training, weapons, served as host facilities for terrorist organizations and sometimes provided sabotage materials,'' said Heller. Israeli intelligence officials noted that Eastern European support for Palestinian guerrilla groups has considerably dropped in the past year, a trend they expected to continue. ``I wouldn't be surprised if that activity stopped completely,'' Heller said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry to Seek Treatment for Unspecified Health Problem
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 7-8, beginning ``The Washington xxx to include reports on treatment plans and shifting of political support to Jackson
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, acknowledging that he needs ``to heal my body, mind and soul,'' but declining to mention drug abuse, announced Sunday that he will seek help following his arrest on a cocaine possession charge. ``He has reached the hour of reckoning,'' said his wife, Effi. At times blinking back tears, the mayor provided no further details on what kind of assistance he will seek, except to say that social activist and self-described nutritional expert Dick Gregory has been consulting him on how to get help. An aide said Barry's main problem was with alcoholism. Top advisers to the mayor, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the mayor was considering checking into the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage, Calif. and two unnamed clinics in the Washington area. Later Sunday, one of Barry's top political advisers said the mayor planned to enter a 30-day inpatient treatment program and could leave as early as Monday. The aide, who also asked not to be identified, did not know where the facility was located, but said it was not in Washington. The Washington Post quoted unnamed sources in Monday's editions as saying that while Barry had initially decided to seek treatment at the Betty Ford center, he now is leaning toward an alternative program with Gregory. In another development, the Post said some of Barry's longtime political allies are starting to engage in behind-the-scenes moves to shift their alliances to Jesse Jackson rather than incur their own loss of influence in the event Barry's poltical career is over. Barry's brief statement was the latest chapter in an unfolding drama that has riveted the nation's capital since the mayor was arrested on drug charges last Thursday night. While the mayor did not say whether he is suffering from drug abuse, others did. Herbert O. Reid Sr., one of the mayor's closest personal advisors, said he hoped that from Barry's travails ``we can all learn something about drug addiction.'' ``He's doing the right thing,'' Reid said. ``I am _ we all are _ relieved, because many of us have suspected for some time that he has had a problem.'' ``The most serious problem is alcoholism,'' Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley said. ``The mayor has acknowledged that he has a health concern, and the details are his private matter.'' ``For you to admit that you have a problem ... that you need to make yourself whole again is truly a burden lifted from our souls,'' the mayor's wife said in remarks that followed her husband's. ``For our family it is just the beginning. Barry, surrounded by clergy in a broadcast appearance in front of St. Timothy's Episcopal Church near his home, clasped his wife's hand and said he has come ``face to face with my deepest human failures.'' Barry said, ``these ministers have helped me to keep the strength I need ... I'm going to find a way to heal my body, mind and soul.'' The mayor did not take questions and turned the podium to Mrs. Barry following his brief statement. Attention has been focused on Mrs. Barry in part because the mayor was lured to his arrest by a woman with whom the mayor has been friendly. Barry, 53, was arrested Thursday evening at a downtown hotel in an FBI sting operation. He now faces a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge after testing positive for cocaine in blood and urine tests administered following his arrest. Close advisors to Barry told The Associated Press on Saturday that the mayor has agreed to enter a drug treatment center. The sources said details on the type of treatment and location of the facility were still being worked out. Barry had been poised to announce his bid for a fourth term as mayor on Sunday but his arrest has thrown local politics into convulsions. Several advisers said Barry had agreed to abandon his bid for re-election, and they added that the possibility of his resigning from office was never discussed in Friday and Saturday strategy sessions. ``The issue never came up, because it is so far out there beyond what we are dealing with now,'' said one aide who spoke with Barry several times on Saturday. ``There is no reason for him to resign, because if he did, he would lose the powers of office, the influence, and the ability to generate money for his treatment program and his legal defense.'' One Barry cabinet member suggested that prior grand jury testimony _ in which the mayor has said he denied ever using drugs _ prevented the mayor from making specific references to drug abuse in his short announcement Sunday. ``If he had said he had a cocaine problem or some other form of drug abuse, then he could possibly face a perjury charge,'' said the aide, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. ``He had to be careful.'' The mayor is now faced with a quandary about whether to permanently stay in office because law enforcement officials have said that U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens will not drop the charges against the mayor unless he steps down. Stephens has not commented on that issue directly, but he has suggested he would look favorably on Barry's resigning when deciding how to proceed with other, broader probes of the mayor's activities. During their morning appearance, Barry frequently turned to his wife, who stood by his side, grabbed her hand and squeezed it. With a wan smile on her face, Ms. Barry then patted her husband's hand in a comforting way and whispered to him. In her remarks, Mrs. Barry said: ``I thank God for this day that he has given Marion Barry ... the strength to admit to this whole world that as a mortal being he has reached the hour of reckoning. For he realizes that it is truly in God's hands ... ``We, Christopher (their son) and I will be with you every step of the way.'' Barry said the events of the past several days had been ``more difficult than fighting my way out of poverty'' or struggling in the civil rights movement, because ``I spent so much time doing for others that I have not worried enough about ... caring for myself.'' ``I realize I'm going to have to walk this journey by myself,'' said Barry. When the short event was over, Barry slowly walked across the street to his home, staring straight ahead and ignoring the questions from a sea of reporters trailing him. But when one bystander shouted ``Hang in there Mr. Barry, you've been a great mayor,'' Barry flashed a broad grin and waved a campaigner's wave for a moment before his smile disappeared and his arm fell limply to his side.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Records Indicate Data Leaked by Supreme Court Justice
DOC.TEXT: The late U.S. Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas violated court confidentiality in 1966 by leaking information to President Johnson, a history professor said, citing newly released FBI records. The alleged leaks about court deliberations to the White House and the FBI involved information that might discredit Robert F. Kennedy, a former attorney general and political rival of Johnson. The documents, released to Marquette University history professor Athan Theoharis under the Freedom of Information Act, were outlined in The Milwaukee Journal on Sunday. FBI files say Fortas, who died in 1982, was cautioned by the agency he would violate judicial ethics by reporting on private discussions among the court's justices, the paper said. The records show Fortas, Johnson and White House aides saw an opportunity to associate Kennedy with an illegal eavesdropping incident that occurred while he was attorney general in 1963, the paper said. Fortas discussed the case with the White House. ``It raises real questions about Fortas' role on the court and the degree with which he identified with the partisan interests and anti-Kennedy forces in the Johnson administration,'' Theoharis, author of a 1988 book on FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover, told the paper. Fortas resigned from the court in 1969 during an unrelated ethics matter. Hoover died in 1972 and Johnson in 1973. Theoharis said the files show Fortas violated the Constitution's doctrine of separation of court and executive power by agreeing to provide inside information to FBI assistant director C.D. De Loach. ``He should have thrown De Loach out on his ear,'' Theoharis said. De Loach, now retired, told the Journal in a telephone interview from Hilton Head Island, S.C., that he could recall nothing of the case discussed in the files. The case involved bugging of a hotel room occupied by Fred Black, a Washington, D.C., lobbyist who was appealing a fraud conviction to the high court. Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall disclosed the the bugging. A memo written by Hoover June 14, 1966, said Fortas called Marshall ``dumb.'' Marshall now sits on the Supreme Court. The court suspended deliberations in the Black case and asked Attorney General Nicholas Katzenbach if the FBI bugging was authorized. Because Kennedy was attorney general at the time of the bugging, there appeared an opportunity to discredit him, the newspaper said. A memorandum by De Loach quoted Fortas as saying ``the entire matter boiled down to a continuing fight for the presidency.'' Fortas volunteered to talk ``on a confidential basis at any time,'' it said. The Theoharis documents show Fortas told De Loach the justices ``held a confidential meeting among themselves'' and decided to review FBI records before ruling on the Black appeal. Fortas suggested a plan to De Loach ``to protect the president and the FBI'' by appointing a pro-Johnson arbitrator to review FBI eavesdropping policy, bypassing Katzenbach, the documents said. Fortas telephoned De Loach June 21 to say Johnson was appointing a three-member eavesdropping investigation panel. Johnson changed his mind two days later, a De Loach memo said. The Justice Department said in July 1966 that Hoover authorized the bugging under authority delegated by one or more of Kennedy's predecessors as attorney general. In November, the Supreme Court ordered a new trial for Black, calling the bugging illegal. Black was subsequently acquitted. Katzenbach, interviewed by telephone in New Jersey, said the documents' disclosures surprised him. ``You think you know what's going on and you don't,'' Katzenbach said. Scott Anderson, a co-author of the 1979 investigative book ``The Brethen'' about the high court, said the documents seem to show an unprecedented breach of Supreme Court tradition and procedure. ``This screams impropriety,'' said Geoffrey Miller, a University of Chicago law professor. Codes of ethics forbid judges from discussing judicial deliberations outside a courtroom, he said. ``It's disgraceful,'' said Harvard Law School professor Charles Fried.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with Stanwyck obit, ADDS Hosch obit. AMs separate on Stanwyck moved as a0669.
DOC.TEXT: Emmy-winning actress Barbara Stanwyck, the sultry villainess of the film classic ``Double Indemnity'' and stern matriarch of television's ``The Big Valley,'' died Saturday of heart failure. She was 82. Miss Stanwyck's career spanned the chorus line, vaudeville, movies, television and won her three Emmys and an honorary Oscar. She appeared in more than 80 movies since the 1920s, including four Academy Award-nominated roles: ``Stella Dallas'' in 1937, ``Ball of Fire'' in 1942 with Gary Cooper, ``Double Indemnity'' with Fred MacMurray and Edward G. Robinson in 1944, and ``Sorry Wrong Number'' with Burt Lancaster in 1948. Her only Oscar, however, was an honorary statuette presented in 1982 for the body of her work. Her television career was equally distinguished. ``The Barbara Stanwyck Show'' ran from September 1960 to September 1961. She hosted the program of half-hour plays and appeared in most episodes. She received Emmy awards in 1961 for ``The Barbara Stanwyck Show,'' in 1966 for her role in ``The Big Valley,'' and in 1983 for the miniseries ``Thorn Birds.'' The American Film Institute gave her its most prestigious honor, the Life Achievement Award, in 1987.

Naruhiko Higashikuni, 102, a member of the imperial family who became Japan's first prime minister after World War II, died Saturday. Higashikuni was the first imperial family member to head a Cabinet. He formed it two days after Japan surrendered to the allies on August 15, 1945, at the request of the late Emperor Hirohito. His Cabinet, however, lasted less than two months because of general confusion in the country during the immediate postwar period. In October 1947, Higashikuni left the imperial family to become a commoner.

Dean S. Butler, a tax attorney for President Richard M. Nixon, died Wednesday of heart failure, relatives said. He was 69. Butler, who lived in Nixon's hometown of Whittier for nearly 40 years, successfully arranged refinancing for Nixon's San Clemente estate after Nixon's 1974 resignation from the presidency. He also successfully defended Nixon against a move to remove him from the California state bar. Butler is survived by his wife, Jean, a son, Bob, and two grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Edward J. Hosch Jr.
DOC.TEXT: Edward J. ``Chick'' Hosch Jr., a sportswriter for The Associated Press in Atlanta from 1941 to 1948 and the first sports publicity director for Georgia Tech, died Friday of cancer. He was 78. Hosch was Tech's sports publicity director from 1951 to 1968. Survivors include his wife, Carole; a son; two daughters; and two stepsons.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Dead in Azerbaijani Capital After Troops Move In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 5th pvs `Azerbaijani President...' to UPDATE with report of Soviet troops in control; pickup graf 6 pvs ```The people....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY33; LaserGraphic NY9
DOC.TEXT: Soviet soldiers waged fierce street battles with militants Saturday in the southern republic of Azerbaijan, and at least 57 people were killed, the government said. Witnesses said the death toll could be far higher. ``The street is covered with blood,'' Vadim Korsh, an editor of Azerbaijan's official news agency, Azerinform, said of the scene at a military garrison in the capital, Baku. One activist said more than 100 local troops at the garrison joined the militants in fighting Soviet soldiers, thousands of which were sent to quell a week of ethnic and separatist violence. It was the first report of rebellion in local ranks. By evening, residents were reporting that the sound of gunfire had stopped in the barracks and elsewhere in the city center. Early Sunday, Moscow Radio said Soviet forces were in control of the city, though some gunfire could still be heard. The report, quoted by the British Broadcasting Corp., said the first night of a curfew passed in relative calm, with 18 people arrested for violating the curfew. Azerbaijani President Elmira Kafarova on Saturday denounced the ``gross violation of the republic's sovereignty'' by the Kremlin's declaration of a state of emergency without the approval of local authorities. ``The people of Azerbaijan will never forgive anyone for the tragic way their sons and daughters have been killed,'' she said. In Moscow, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went on nationwide TV to appeal for an end to the violence that the government says has killed more than 129 people, wounded 500 and chased thousands of Armenians from their homes. ``In the last two years, the central authorities have sought to act in a patient and thoughtful manner, trying to solve difficult problems exclusively by peaceful, political means,'' Gorbachev said. But militants had begun threatening to take over the government by force and are killing people, he said. ``This had to stop,'' said Gorbachev, who also has had to deal with nationalist movements in other republics, including neighboring Georgia, Moldavia and the Baltics. In Washington, the Bush administration called for ``restraint in the use of force'' and said the sending of troops to stop the violence should not ``become a cloak for the abridgment of the exercise of political rights.'' Iran, which borders Azerbaijan, urged the Soviet government to ``resolve the issue by employing peaceful means.'' Moscow sent troops to Baku after fighting flared between the Moslem Azerbaijanis and mainly Christian Armenians. The neighboring republics are locked in a decades-old dispute over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is inside Azerbaijan but populated mainly by Armenians. Speakers at rallies in Baku were reported to have demanded secession from the Soviet Union and unification with Iran. Some 5,000 regular army troops and thousands more Interior Ministry soldiers and police have moved in to try to restore order. Araz Ali-Zade, of the opposition Azerbaijani Social Democratic Group, said 120 Azeribaijani soldiers under the command of a colonel spent the afternoon in a pitched battle with Soviet troops in the Salyanovsky Barracks in downtown Baku. By evening the shooting stopped, he said in a telephone interview from the city, but he had no further details. The official Tass news agency quoted Deputy Defense Ministry Gen. Valentin Varennikov as saying militants surrounded the barracks and that troops who moved in to defend it were attacked by snipers firing heavy-caliber machine guns from rooftops. The soldiers ``opened warning fire only in defense of strategic sites and their own lives. If the attacks didn't stop, they fired only on those who were threatening them,'' he said. The Interior Ministry reported 51 civilians and six soldiers dead Saturday. It said 287 civilians and 36 soldiers were wounded. Korsh said in a telephone interview from Baku that corpses were strewn on the road to the city's airport. It was impossible to independently verify government casualty figures, as foreign reporters have been barred from the region. Azerbaijani activists claimed the number of dead climbed into the thousands after armored personnel carriers surrounded a central square in Baku and opened fire with machine guns. But Arif Yunosof of the Azerbaijani Social Democratic Group said the troops fired into the air in a vain attempt to dispel the crowd of 30,000 to 40,000 people. Troops moved into Baku, a Caspian Sea port of 1.8 million people, early Saturday. Army and internal security troops have been building up in Armenia and Azerbaijan for several days, but they previously had not entered Baku. Soldiers surrounded a square near the Communist Party headquarters, where about 30,000 Azerbaijanis gathered in an anti-government protest, said Leila Unusova, also of the Azerbaijani Social Democrat Group. The biggest battles reportedly raged around the airport and military garrison, where armed protesters had been trying to prevent troop reinforcements from traveling to the strife-torn areas. The Azerbaijan Communist Party chief, Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov, was fired and replaced by two people: Azerbaijan Premier Ayaz Mutalibov and party second secretary Viktor Polyanichko, Tass reported. Censorship was in full force as part of the state of emergency. Tass had photographs of soldiers fighting civilians, but editors said they were not permitted to release them. Radio Moscow said the measure forbids strikes and street processions, the use of duplicating equipment, and the use of transport without special permission. The first deputy foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, told reporters the measures and introduction of troops had improved the situation. But the reports of mass rallies and the continued sound of gunshots ringing out in the capital indicated otherwise. Adding to the problems were daring political moves by Azerbaijanis. The legislature of the Nakhichevan Autonomous Republic, which is controlled by the republic, voted to secede from Azerbaijan as well as from the U.S.S.R., news reports said. Nakhichevan is a small enclave of about 250,000 people, surrounded by Armenia, Iran and Turkey. It has been under Azerbaijan's jurisdiction since 1924. Violence broke out there Jan. 1 when demonstrators forced open the border with Iran in an effort to be reunited with their brethren in that country. Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency said the Supreme Soviet legislature in Nakhichevan demanded Soviet troops leave the enclave and appealed to Turkey, Iran and the United Nations for support.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Woo Youth, Women With Patriotism, Patronage, Cowboy Boots
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When American adventurer William Walker set fire to this handsome colonial city in 1856, the citizens are said to have hidden their gold in holes in the ground or in thick adobe walls. Among the remnants of that episode is the Granadinos' tendency to tap on walls, hoping for a hollow sound, and the memory of the U.S. invader who stuck a sign in the smoldering ruins with a cynical message: ``Here was Granada.'' When he came here for a campaign rally, President Daniel Ortega seized on that 133-year-old memory to drive home one of the Sandinistas' messages _ they represent the defense of national sovereignty in the face of U.S. intervention. ``Times haven't changed that much,'' Ortega told some 6,000 Granadinos who recently gathered at the central park for a rally. ``The Yankees are still trying.''' In one campaign appearance after another, Ortega plays the Sandinistas' top drawing cards _ patriotism, patronage and packaging. He is taking aim at two important blocs as he tries for another six-year term in the Feb. 25 elections _ women and youth. ``This is a young country. The young people are the future. They are our future,'' said one Sandinista militant whose job is to observe rallies. The voting age in Nicaragua is 16, and an estimated 46 percent of Nicaraguans are under 15 years of age. Women, especially those in the 16-35 age bracket, are also an important bloc. They normally are 51 percent of the population but are an even greater percentage now; more than 12 years of armed conflict has killed thousands of men and left others refugees or members of the Contra army ranks. Early in the campaign, Ortega, a young-looking 44, was repackaged to create a new image. ``Daniel, President of the Young,'' proclaim posters, billboards and grafitti, many of them around university campuses and schools. The president traded his prescription glasses for contact lenses. He switched from his sober trademark camouflage uniform to black T-shirts worn under cotton bomber jackets with sleeves rolled up. He started wearing cowboy boots. In December, Ortega started dancing with skimpily clad beauty queens. In Granada he danced on stage with Marucha, a barefoot and aproned food vendor known for her ``chancho con yuca,'' a favorite Nicaraguan dish of fried pork rinds with yucca. The crowd was delighted. A regular feature at Sandinista rallies is a session where Ortega poses with children for photographs. Dour-faced state security agents lean down from the 7-foot-high speaking platform to pick up tiny babies whose parents want to go home with an instant picture of junior and the president. Like most rallies, the Granada rally was followed by a ceremony honoring relatives of war victims. This time it was a dinner at Granada's best hotel for members of the Mothers of Heroes and Martyrs, a Sandinista organization. With few Nicaraguan families untouched by the war between the Sandinistas and the U.S.-backed Contra rebels, and with most people unable to afford restaurants, the gesture will likely be remembered. Josefa Salinas, the 22-year-old daughter of a poor peasant family, waited in a broiling sun, then a downpour, for Ortega to appear. Ms. Salinas, from the nearby community of El Capulin, graduated in December from a Granada technical school with a degree in accounting. ``Before, I would not have been able to study. Before, you had to pay. Now it's free,'' she said. Ms. Salinas was 12 years old when the Sandinistas came to power in July 1979 and ousted dictator Anastasio Somoza. The irony is that while the Sandinistas have made it possible for a poor peasant child such as Ms. Salinas to obtain an education, now that she has it, she can't find work. Unemployment among Nicaraguan youth is widespread and unabating. ``I'm looking. But there doesn't seem to be any work,'' she said. However, her vote will be ``100 percent, totally'' for the Sandinista Front. Why? ``It's the way they are carrying out the revolutionary process, how they treat the people,'' she said. ``Before, with the Somocistas, the government would deal only with the rich people and the gringos, just among themselves. Now we are taken into account.'' Ms. Salina's father was an itinerant peasant who rented his labor to large landowners under Somoza. The Sandinista government gave him land through agrarian reform and he now works in a farm cooperative. The Sandinistas have exercised their patronage as the ruling party and handed out hundreds of land and home titles to Nicaraguan families; they've given taxi cooperatives easy credit to buy new cars; government workers have obtained pay raises. Party pins and other symbols of recognition have been distributed like candy, as have T-shirts, baseball caps, tote bags, belt buckles, kerchiefs, pens, cigarette lighters and posters. The Sandinista Youth, an organization for men and women roughly between ages 15 and 30, harnesses that force for party purposes. The government sponsors popular dances with local and foreign bands and promotes sports; belonging to it means preferential treatment in obtaining scholarships and other advantages. High school student Marta Lorena Mendoza, 18, said she joined the Sandinista Youth four days before the rally and had been sent out everyday to hand out leaflets announcing Ortega's arrival. ``Everybody in the neighborhood belongs to the Sandinista Youth,'' she said. ``My cousin,'' an older boy who is in the Sandinista army, ``told me I should join.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Candidate Back on Campaign Trail
With AM-Nicaragua-Sandinistas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The top opposition presidential candidate jumped back onto the campaign trail over the weekend after knee surgery, dismissing government suggestions she may withdraw from the race. Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition, or UNO, pledged peace and prosperity during a speech to supporters Saturday in the southern town of San Rafael Del Sur. She said her coalition would ban the draft if it wins general elections Feb. 25. She is challenging President Daniel Ortega, who is seeking another six-year term. Mrs. Chamorro, 60, wore a cast on her left leg and sat in a wheelchair as she spoke from the back of a pickup truck in this town, an opposition stronghold. About 3,000 people gathered to hear Mrs. Chamorro and other UNO candidates. UNO leaders say they have received little of the $9 million appropriated for Nicaragua in October by the U.S. Congress. About $2 million is meant as direct aid to UNO and the rest is to support the general electoral process. While the ruling leftist Sandinista Front has handed out thousands of T-shirts, pins, pens, cigarette lighters, baseball caps, tote bags and other such items, most UNO slogans appear as graffiti scrawled on walls. ``Now they (Sandinistas) are distributing little gifts to buy votes,'' Mrs. Chamorro told the crowd. ``I say, take the T-shirt, put a little bleach on it, take Daniel's name off and put your own name on it if you want,'' she told a cheering crowd. Clothing, even a T-shirt, is expensive for most Nicaraguans. ``As if the country could forget 10 years of war because of a T-shirt,'' Mrs. Chamorro said, referring to the civil war between the leftist government and U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The widow of revered civic leader Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, and the publisher of La Prensa, Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper, Mrs. Chamorro received the backing of 14 parties _ ranging from conservatives to communists _ that united to form an anti-Sandinista bloc. Mrs. Chamorro suffers from osteoporosis, an illness that makes bones brittle, and she fractured her knee when she fell at home Dec. 31. She underwent surgery at a Houston clinic, where President Bush telephoned twice to inquire about her health. She returned last week to Nicaragua. Ortega has suggested repeatedly that UNO might withdraw from the elections, label them a fraud and invite a U.S. invasion like the one last month in Panama. Mrs. Chamorro and running mate Virgilio Godoy of the Independent Liberal Party have repeatedly denied plans to withdraw. Mrs. Chamorro assured the crowd that ``I take a pill for the pain'' and will keep campaigning. Polls have shown that voters' top concerns are ending the two-year draft, obligatory for 16-year-old boys, ending the civil war, and reviving a moribund economy. Since the U.S. invasion of Panama, the Sandinistas have said they expect Nicaragua to be the next target of an invasion, but the State Department has dismissed such talk. Mrs. Chamorro said Saturday she was ``allergic'' to weapons and derided Ortega's claims of wanting peace while keeping the largest armed forces by far in Central America. They are estimated at about 150,000 members, including militias and reserves. ``With your vote, you can say goodbye to the obligatory military service (draft) and to inflation forever,'' she said. Hyperinflation of 36,000 percent for 1988 was brought down to 1,600 percent last year after the government put into effect an austerity program, according to government figures. However, some economists believe the inflation rate is actually higher.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed as Truck Falls into River
DOC.TEXT: A truck fell into a river in southern Nepal, killing 11 of its riders and injuring 11, the Home Ministry said Sunday. The truck fell Friday into the Supa River near Butwal, 115 miles south of Katmandu, a ministry announcement said. On the same day, 25 people, including two Californians, were killed when two buses collided head-on at Adhuwa Mandrebhir, 95 miles west of Katmandu.

DOC.HEAD: China To Launch Arab Satellite
DOC.TEXT: China's Great Wall Foundation has been chosen to launch an Arab communications satellite, the official Xinhua News Agency said Sunday. The satellite will be launched at the end of 1991 for the Arab Organization for Satellite Communications, a network that groups Oman, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Morocco, Iraq, Syria and Jordan. Arabsat, as it is also known, already has two satellites in orbit. Xinhua said China's bid was selected at an Arabsat meeting last week, and the choice was announced by Mohamed Shaheen Ismail, director-general of the group's Jordan office. Great Wall is China's commercial satellite-launching venture. It has negotiated several launches in recent years but none has taken off. In December, President Bush gave approval for it to launch three U.S.-made satellites over the next two years for Hong Kong and Australian owners. China has sent 25 of its own satellites into space since 1970.

DOC.HEAD: 37 Men Arrested in Connection with Attack on Algiers Courthouse
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested 37 Moslem fundamentalists in connection with an attack at a trial in an Algerian courthouse that killed three people, the French news agency Agence France-Presse reported Sunday. A Shiite Moslem group, the Tradition of the Prophet and Islamic Law, claimed responsibility for the attack, which was stopped by a gunbattle that killed an 18-year-old gendarme and two of the assailants. The incident occurred Tuesday in Blida, an Algiers suburb. Several assailants yelling ``God is great!'' burst into the courtroom and took several hostages during the trial of an elderly man accused of killing his wife. Authorities surrounded the courtroom, and gunfire broke out. The hostages were freed. An investigating magistrate on Saturday night began questioning the 37 men, who were arrested in the area, AFP said. Four men had been charged with taking hostages and mounting an attack with a deadly weapon, the news agency said. Police had no idea what prompted the attack and knew little about the group that claimed responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Agencies' Use of Contractors Ruled Improper
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department improperly used private contractors to write congressional testimony for Energy Secretary James D. Watkins and to review security clearances, the General Accounting Office said Sunday. The GAO, an arm of the Congress that acts as the government's auditor, also ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency improperly used a contractor to run a telephone hotline to answer questions from the public about the agency's Superfund program of cleaning up the worst hazardous waste sites. The contracts in these three cases should be modified or terminated, the GAO said, ``to ensure that these inherently governmental functions are not performed by contractors.'' ``The GAO's decision is confirmation that something has gone very wrong when government officials are no more than mouthpieces or rubber stamps for testimony, rules and decisions prepared by private contractors,'' said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., who had asked GAO to review the contracts. Pryor is chairman of the federal services subcommittee of the Governmental Affairs Committee and a longtime critic of federal agencies' reliance on contractors. EPA spokeswoman Robin Woods said the agency planned to retain the contract. ``We have made a decision to use our limited resources in areas which must be addressed by civil servants, such as in the development of regulations and policies, while contracting out for technical information services,'' Ms. Woods said. At the Energy Department, spokeswoman Catherine Kaliniak said the department would not comment until it had reviewed the auditors' decision. The Energy Department has come under increasing criticism by Congress for its heavy reliance on contractors. The department has about 16,000 federal workers and more than 100,000 contract employees. Watkins has complained publicly that his agency does not have enough money to hire federal workers to perform the scientific and other technical work that currently is done by contractors. Pryor's subcommittee disclosed last November that employees of the contractor Systematic Management Services and those of one of its subcontractors, BDM Corp., had written the testimony that Watkins gave before the House Armed Services Committee on April 3, 1989, on the nuclear weapons complex. The GAO said that in addition to writing Watkins' testimony, Systematic Management Services also prepared answers to congressional inquiries resulting from Watkins' confirmation hearing last February, and prepared briefing books and other materials for Watkins for congressional hearings. Although the GAO decision made no mention of it, Pryor's subcommittee has charged also that contractors prepared testimony for other senior Energy Department officials, including Leo Duffy, Watkins' chief adviser on waste management. The GAO said the department has admitted that this use of contractors violated the department's own rules. More broadly, the auditors said, the preparation of congressional testimony is government work that should be done only by federal employees. The GAO also said the Energy Department was wrong to hire Maxima Corp. of Bethesda, Md., to hear evidence in security clearance cases. Hearing officers provided by Maxima do not grant clearances, but they make recommendations to department managers on granting, denying or revoking clearances, the auditors said. Maxima employees also serve as examiners who hear appeals of security clearance decisions. This contract also calls for Maxima to do psychiatric evaluations of security clearance applicants, according to department records made available to The Associated Press. It also is to audit computerized files of personnel security information on 240,000 individuals and correct inaccuracies in the files. The department asserted to the GAO that the Maxima contract was proper because the hearing officers and examiners do not make final decisions on security clearances. The auditors ruled, however, that these are ``quasi-judicial services which are inherently governmental functions that should not be procured by contract.'' Last July, the Energy Department revealed in a classified hearing of the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee that contract employees were used to conduct interviews of applicants for the highest level security clearances at nuclear arms plants. It said this was done because there were not enough federal staffers available, even though it violates written department policy. A sanitized transcript of that hearing was released last month. In the EPA case reviewed by the GAO, the auditors said GEO-Resource Consultants Inc. of San Francisco has been on the agency's payroll since 1980 to operate the Superfund hotline. The auditors said this arrangement raises questions ``concerning the amount of discretion and value judgment'' used by the contractor in answering questions about certain environmental laws. The EPA contends that the hotline contract is proper because the contractor ``is merely a conduit for information'' and is not making decisions for the government. GAO disagreed, saying the contract employees, in responding to caller's questions, use their own judgment to interpret EPA regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Revolution In Romania Causes Jitters In Beijing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf pvs, `Of the...' to CORRECT to East European, sted East German. Pickup 3rd pvs, ``But while...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The tumultuous revolution in Romania, culminating in the execution of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, sent shivers down the spines of the Chinese leadership. Of the East European countries that experienced pro-democracy movements, Romania had the best relations with China. There also were similarities in their relative economic and political developments. But while the Romanian people succeeded in their revolution, the Chinese student movement, which preceded the changes in Bucharest and around Eastern Europe by six months, failed. Several critical differences between the two countries helped China's rulers. Their economy was stronger than Romania's. Their troops remained loyal. And Romania's revolution was watched by the benevolent eye of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, while China's students had little but ample air time on Western TV. A fear of chaos in China, brought on by nightmarish memories of the ultra-leftist Cultural Revolution, also helped the Beijing's hard-liners. The question _ Why not China? _ is being pondered not only by those who study Beijing, but by those who run it. Western and Chinese sources report meetings are being held weekly, and even daily, among Communist Party cells, government units and the military to stress the leadership's view of the Romanian revolution as an ``anti-socialist uprising,'' much like the ``counterrevolutionary uprising'' of Beijing in the spring of 1989. After Ceausescu's execution, more troops were rushed to Beijing to prevent demonstrations. One Hong Kong magazine reports that some senior cadres ``were unable to eat'' upon hearing of the dictator's demise. Why did the tumult in Timisoara touch such a tender nerve among the Chinese leadership? Romania had the closest ties with China in Eastern Europe and was in lockstep with the Beijing leadership on many issues of practical and political importance. Both countries at early dates in their Communist history distanced themselves from the Soviet Union's foreign policy. Both revered the discredited Soviet dictator Josef Stalin. There were reports Ceausescu considered seeking refuge in Beijing as he fell from power. Romania's political structure also closely resembled China's. Ceausescu was a dictator who placed family members in important positions to perpetuate his Communist dynasty. China for most of the past decade has remained in the hands of one man _ Deng Xiaoping. Nepotism is rife. But in June of 1989, the differences between the two countries proved critical. When Deng seized power in 1978, he launched a reform program that doubled China's gross national product in a decade, gave land back to the peasants and sparked a marked increase in the average standard of living. The economic reforms did not come with any concrete political changes. Periods of relative liberalism were followed by crackdowns on ``bourgeois liberalism'' and ``spiritual polllution,'' buzzwords for democratic yearnings. But the people were not hungry, and their anger during the June pro-democracy movement turned quickly to fear. The bloodiest part of the crackdown lasted a weekend. In Romania, meanwhile, Ceausescu choked his economy in his drive to repay foreign debt, sparking the most pervasive shortages in Eastern Europe. Among the people, hunger and exasperation with another winter without coal, oil or electricity led to desperation _ enough that people would risk their lives to complete the revolution. Romania's military was not immune to these influences. And by apparently killing at least one military commander, the Securitate forces alienated themselves from the regular troops, a fatal mistake. In China, the military remained loyal to the state. One reason is that China does not have a special security force separate from the military and was thus spared the possibilities of such a confrontation. Another is that China's army was born from a true national liberation struggle in the 1920s and has a long history of loyalty to the Communist Party. Despite its economic quagmire, Romania passed through several decades of relative political stability before its revolution. In the 1960s, China suffered the ultra-leftist Cultural Revolution, during which millions were killed as Mao Tse-tung sought to purge his country of bourgeois influences. The experience left many Chinese fearful of mass movements. In the minds of many Chinese, the government justified its oppression by evoking fears of the chaos of not so long ago. But now the Chinese leadership appears to be sowing the seeds for the next round of chaos. It is dismantling the very reform program that saved it. Leading reformers have been purged. Small-scale private and collectively owned enterprises are being closed throughout the country, putting millions out of work. Peasants are again being forced to grow grain, thereby sacrificing the lucrative vegetable market. The government has taken to issuing them IOU's that have no deadline for collection. Workers' salaries are effectively being cut as the government pays an increasingly high percentage of their wages in non-negotiable bonds. Further blows have been struck by a fall in foreign investments. One respected Hong-Kong based consultants' group recently branded China the riskiest investment in Asia _ even worse than the Philippines, which is still reeling from the bloody coup attempt in December. More trouble seems inevitable. The worry is that the next flurry might not be centered on the students, who with their marches and hunger strikes made non-violence a way of life. China's next round of trouble might come from the countryside or the inner cities, led by a people schooled in the art of discourse. dashes:
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: John Pomfret covered the pro-democracy movement in China for The Associated Press. He is now based in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Two Reputed Witchdoctors Killed in Mob Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A mob of 40 people stoned to death a 72-year-old woman reputed to be a witch doctor, and hundreds of attackers with clubs killed another purported witch doctor, authorities said. The mob kidnapped and then stoned to death L.E. Ndovela in the Nakotanene township in the southeastern province of Natal, police said in a statement Saturday. Their report also said an unidentified man thought to be witch doctor was killed by about 200 attackers with clubs in Siledile, a township near the border with Swaziland. The statement did not say when the attacks occurred. Both victims and attackers were black. No arrests were made in either case.

DOC.HEAD: Lobbyist Dons Blue Suit to Battle Official Cover-ups
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: When Congress returns this week, lobbyist Kevin Kearney will climb out of his hot tub, slip into a conservative blue suit and head for Capitol Hill to give America's 35,000 card-carrying nudists some national exposure. ``We need to come out of the closet,'' says Kearney, the first full-time lobbyist for the Florida-based American Sunbathing Association. Kearney, 38, an avid outdoorsman, has become an enthusiastic convert to ``clothing-optional'' recreation since he was hired last March by the oldest and biggest nudist organization in the country. He conducts business from an office in his suburban Cabin John, Md., home, and has installed a telephone in the backyard next to his bubbling hot tub, where he makes calls while skinny-dipping. ``It's a good place to work,'' he says. In his battle against government cover-ups, Kearney works closely with Turner V. Stokes, a Leesburg, Va., computer specialist and longtime nudist who founded NUDEPAC, a nudist political action committee, five years ago. ``We're mad as hell, and we won't take it anymore,'' says Stokes, borrowing from the line made popular by the movie ``Network.'' Kearney already has lobbied the National Park Service and other federal agencies to issue regulations guaranteeing nudists the right to enjoy swimming, camping, hiking, white-water ``canuding'' and other recreational activities on public lands. His next targets are the 65 members of House and Senate committees with jurisdiction over public lands. He recently mailed each of them a copy of the ASA's artsy new wall calendar for 1990, featuring photos of nudes romping in the Grand Canyon, splashing in Colorado hot springs and scaling snow-covered California mountain peaks. Only two legislators responded. A California Democrat wrote back asking for more calendars. An Iowa Republican's envelope came back unopened and stamped ``Return to Sender.'' Undaunted, Kearney is pondering several other gimmicks to improve the nudist image among Washington power brokers. He's thinking of inviting every member of Congress to a nearby Maryland nudist camp this summer to shed their inhibitions, press the flesh and enjoy some barbecue in the buff. On National Nude Weekend in mid-July, Kearney may lead a bare-bottomed sailboat regatta down the Potomac River to challenge federal, state and local anti-nudity regulations. He's also ready to propose a federal excise tax on bathing suits, which he calls ``a piece of totally useless recreational equipment.'' There are no federal laws outlawing nudity. Spokesmen for the National Park Service, the U.S. Forest Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority say nudists generally are welcome on public lands unless their activities are forbidden by local statutes or threaten to disturb the tranquility of wilderness areas. But George Berklacy, a National Park Service spokesman, had discouraging news for Kearney. ``We have no intention of developing regulations which allow for nude sunbathing,'' he said. Kearney complained that without uniform federal regulations, unsuspecting nudists run the risk of arbitrary eviction by hostile park rangers, some of whom have threatened their au naturel visitors with guns or handcuffs. ``Our people have lost many beaches over the last decade, and they're frustrated and tired of being hassled,'' he said. ``This sort of thing would never be allowed to happen to surf casters or tennis players or golfers.'' Kearney is convinced that despite all the prejudice and snickering, an estimated 40 million Americans _ many of them well-educated, highly paid professionals _ ``have participated in nude recreation at some time,'' from neighborhood hot tub parties to vacations on Yugoslavia's famed nude beaches. ``All of a sudden, Americans are going to change their attitudes quickly,'' he predicted. ``All they need is a catalyst.'' What kind of catalyst? ``It's going to happen when people come out of the closet,'' he said, ``when you get a president of the United States who'll go on television and admit that he's a nudist.''

DOC.HEAD: New NY Police Commissioner Used to Unwelcome Mat
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Lee Patrick Brown, who takes office Monday as New York's 36th police commissioner, has made a career of tackling troubled police departments. Nicknamed ``the Iceman,'' he is known as a cool, deliberate _ some say stiff _ administrator who meticulously studies problems before acting. His supporters say the 52-year-old Brown is a dedicated crime fighter prepared to tackle the nation's largest city. They call him a a thinking person's cop who recognizes the importance of fighting crime at its roots, including trying to correct the social ills that foster criminals. His detractors say he is more a politician than a policeman, garnering good publicity for the department while the police force unravels from within. When Brown became public safety commissioner in Atlanta in 1978, the department was reeling from a series of child murders that shocked the nation, anti-discrimination lawsuits and a promotion examinations scandal. In 1982, he was appointed police chief in Houston, a city where the police had a trigger-happy reputation. By the time he left both cities, both police departments had won praise and many officials begged him to stay. Two recent incidents in Houston in which white or Hispanic officers have shot and killed black motorists have once again tarnished the department's image, but Brown emerged relatively unscathed. Just before he left Houston, he fired the officers involved. His resume is impressive, with a Ph.D. in criminology and a master's degree in sociology. He's been a patrolman in San Jose, Calif., and a professor at Portland State and Howard universities. Brown's past is not without controversy, however, and he has received a cold shoulder from New York police as he prepares to take over the nation's largest police department. When new Mayor David Dinkins tapped Brown, he was going against the wishes of Gov. Mario Cuomo, former Mayor Edward I. Koch and the Patrolman's Benevolent Association; all supported the retention of Richard Condon, who had served as police commissioner since the retirement of Ben Ward in October. Numerous officers have told the press that they resent Brown winning the job over the popular Condon, but the patrolmen's association has taken a wait-and-see attitude. The organization's response certainly has been more restrained than that of Houston police when he was named as the first black chief there. They sent ``truth squads'' to Atlanta to check on their new boss. ``They were pretty hard on him but we have no reason to do that,'' said Joseph Mancini, a spokesman for the New York patrolmen's association. Richard Murray, a political pollster at the University of Houston, said Brown is very good at public relations. The popularity of Houston police shot up during Brown's first few years. ``He's a Ph.D. and that doesn't hurt,'' Murray said. ``He's worked his way up.'' All agree that Brown loves criminology jargon and terminology, sprinkling his conversations with bureaucratic phrases like ``problem-solving analysis'' and ``patrol-management plans.'' ``He's not exactly a quote machine,'' said J.C. Mosier, a Houston police spokesman. Once, when he testified in the trial of Wayne Williams, the man convicted in some of the Atlanta child murders, an exasperated defense attorney asked Brown if he spoke English. Nor is he a popular guy in the Houston police department. Police groups say that Brown did what Mayor Kathy Whitmire wanted him to do and did little to better the life of the average police officer. Still smarting from the collapse of the domestic oil market, Houston has been unable to afford a police cadet class since 1986, with attrition shrinking the police force to about 3,900 and police receiving only minimal pay raises. When word got out that Brown was going to New York, some Houston police officers sang ``I Love New York,'' over police radios. Houston Police Patrolmen's Union President Mike Howard said Brown ``has hurt morale here terribly. The department has gotten so bad the last couple of years and he has done nothing to help.'' Howard compared him to ``a magician using mirrors, smoke and glitter and the department all looks fine. But, on the inside, the department is falling apart.'' Whitmire said the complaints from police groups come mostly from the old guard officers who resisted Brown's modernization efforts, which include a strong emphasis on minority hiring. ``People in New York will find that he can always be counted on to be very professional, very measured,'' Whitmire said. ``Lee's not a person to shoot from the hip or to go with any decision without it being well thought out.'' Brown says he brings no preconceived notions on how to fight crime in New York. In his calm, precise tone he says he unworried by the lack of a welcome mat. ``Once I get there, I intend to reach out to them. Once I get to meet the people, they'll understand I am a natural at this,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Azerbaijanis Mourn Dead in Moscow Demonstration
LaserPhotos MOSB1, MOSB2
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Azerbaijanis demonstrated Sunday to protest the government's crackdown on ethnic violence in their southern republic and to mourn nationalists who died in the fighting. At the same time, Armenians congregated at a Moscow church and cemetery to mourn their dead and collect money and offer housing for refugees. At least 2,000 Azerbaijanis living in the Soviet capital gathered at the republic's government offices, then marched to the central headquarters of the official news agency Tass, where they protested its portrayal of the crackdown. According to Tass, 51 civilians and six soldiers, died in clashes in Baku, the Azerbaijan capital, on Saturday. Nationalist groups in Azerbaijan and Moscow put the death toll much higher but could not substantiate their figures. The crackdown, ordered by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, came after years of ethnic tensions and territorial disputes between mostly Christian Armenians and predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis in the Caucasus region. The Azerbaijani demonstrators demanded that the chief editor come out of Tass headquarters and explain to them why the news agency was ``distorting'' events in the Azerbaijani capital. When no one emerged, the demonstrators moved off toward the studios of Gostelradio, the state-run television and radio. ``They are not telling the truth,'' said one of the demonstration organizers. ``We are not being told what is really happening in Baku.'' The protesters, many wearing black armbands, waved Azerbaijani flags and held up placards blaming the violence in Armenia and Azerbaijan on Gorbachev. The signs said, ``More Than 1,000 Murdered, Thousands Injured,'' ``Tragedy in Baku _ Reflection of Gorbachev Politics'' and ``Who is Next, Gorbachev?'' Gorbachev told a nationwide television audience Saturday that troops were sent to Baku as a last resort after efforts to solve the Azerbaijani-Armenian conflict peacefully failed. As the Azerbaijanis marched on media offices, Armenians gathered at a church inside the Vagankovsky Cemetery in western Moscow to mourn the dozens of Armenian victims of the ethnic violence. They lit candles and listened to an organ playing somber music inside the small red brick church. Outside, volunteers sat at a table on the snow-covered sidewalk to collect donations for the 15,000 Armenian refugees who fled Baku. Demonstrators outside the church held protest signs, including one that blamed Moscow for the deaths of Armenians killed by Azerbaijanis in clashes before Soviet troops were sent to Baku.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Foes Hope To Keep Debate Alive This Election Year
DOC.TEXT: With a push for new restrictions in legislatures around the country, opponents of abortion hope to keep debate on the issue alive during this election year _ to the discomfort of their Republican allies who'd like to see it go away. ``In 1990 no candidate can run for public office without squarely facing the abortion issue,'' Republican chairman Lee Atwater told GOP officials Friday. Then, with a little less certainty, he added that ``I would hope Republicans support Republican candidates regardless of their position on abortion.'' After losing crucial 1989 elections, anti-abortion leaders were trying to regain the offensive by pressing state legislatures to impose a variety of limits on women's rights to obtain abortions. Abortion-rights leaders say they expect some legislatures will pass some restrictions this year. But they believe they will prevail in most, and that the fights will help shape the 1990 elections for governor, state legislatures and other offices. The two sides in the volatile debate were taking different approaches to Monday's 17th anniversay of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. Opponents of that decision were massing for a march on the U.S. Capitol and planning other demonstrations around the country, while supporters of abortion were concentrating on low-key lobbying activities. Both sides agree the intensifying battles over abortion will dominate many races this year, from Congress to local offices, just as in the few elections last fall. ``Anybody running for anything short of school board is going to be put on the spot,'' said Charles Cook, editor of a Washington political newsletter. ``Everybody up and down the line is going to have to address it.'' Republicans have candidates on both sides of the issue, but under the banner of a party platform that is solidly against abortion and a president who has vetoed abortion-rights bills from Congress. Atwater contends the party ``is big enough to accept different views,'' a position many party conservatives dispute. ``State your position, and move on,'' is the advice Michele Davis, director of the Republican Governors' Association, gives her candidates. ``Don't allow yourself to be immersed in that one and only issue.'' The restrictions sought by the National Right to Life Committee and other anti-abortion groups were made possible by last year's Supreme Court ruling that opened the way for new state limits on abortion. The Webster decision revived political intensity over the issue and thrust it squarely in the hands of the states. While the states may be the main arena, Congress is certain to replay the battles it fought on the margins of the abortion debate last fall. For the first time, the House joined the Senate in voting down restrictions on federally financed abortions for poor women in cases of rape or incest _ prompting President Bush to issue a series of vetos that the pro-choice majority could not override. Abortion-rights advocates say they will try again later this year, presenting the prospects of Bush vetoes just before the fall elections. And even right-to-life leaders concede polls show a majority of public opinion supports allowing abortion in those tragic cases. ``This cuts against the Republicans,'' said Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore. ``It did last year, will this year. I think if there's no movement on their side to a more humane approach on this, it's going to cost them dearly at the polls.'' Abortion-rights supporters also plan to keep the political debate churning by holding hearings this spring on House and Senate bills that would incorporate into federal law the Roe vs. Wade decision. They aren't likely to have enough votes to win passage of the measure, which is aimed at preventing further erosion of abortion rights before the Supreme Court. The right-to-life strategists are basing their hopes for winning new state laws on polls showing that in spite of majority support for keeping abortions legal, there is significant support for some limits on abortions when taken on a case by case basis. For example, a national USA Today poll taken late last month showed 72 percent favored laws requiring notification of parents before a minor may obtain an abortion, and 63 percent support a mandatory 24-hour waiting period. Those type of restrictions are among the half-dozen or so bills the National Right to Life Committee is pushing, though they vary in details by states. ``Anything we can pass will be progress,'' said Burke J. Balch, state legislative coordinator for the National Right to Life Committee. ``We'll be very happy if we can get one of each of these pieces of legislation in one or two states.'' Other restrictions pushed by the right-to-life groups include banning abortions for gender selection; giving fathers rights to block an abortion in court; banning abortions in public facilities and blocking government counseling on abortions; and ``informed consent'' requirements forcing women to receive information about the abortion process and fetal development. But the most significant restriction would bar abortion as a means of birth control _ a catch-all phrase that encompasses 90 percent or more of all abortions.

DOC.HEAD: Baku Unrest Pushes a Reluctant Gorbachev to Use Force
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In both foreign and internal affairs, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is trying to instill the idea of negotiation and law into a country accustomed to the heavy-handed style that filled labor camps and unmarked graves and invaded neighboring countries. Only the threat of civil war and secession overcame Gorbachev's deep reluctance to use force and persuaded him to send troops into the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to stop ethnic fighting between Azerbaijanis and Armenians. Mindful of bloody precedents, Gorbachev first tried to defuse the conflict with decrees, discussions and appeals to use common sense. Gorbachev said he ordered the military to shoot if necessary only when he became convinced he had no alternative. ``It could no longer go on,'' a weary-looking Gorbachev told the nation in a television address Saturday. ``The state is duty-bound to put an end to lawlessness and inhumanity, to resolutely curb criminal actions of extremists who have lost human face, who are prepared to take other people's lives for the sake of personal ambition, selfish interests and power,'' he said. Victims of the conflict as well as the budding political opposition openly second-guess him, accusing Gorbachev of aggravating the problem with indecision. But Gorbachev has staked his reforms on convincing the world that the Soviet Union believes consultation is better than confrontation. Internally, he is removing Moscow's heavy hand in order to shift more responsibility to local authorities. In raising the prestige and power of local authorities, he has assumed that they logically will follow his reform policies, and he has appeared startled and angry when they have not. Until last week, the Soviet leader had deployed Interior Ministry soldiers only to guard vital installations in Armenia and Azerbaijan, and to end bloody attacks on minority Meskhetian Turks in Uzbekistan that left about 100 people dead. Once, when he was out of the country, violence was used against nationalist protesters in the republic of Georgia. Gorbachev had ordered the troops disarmed, so they went in with shovels, killing 19 demonstrators. The deaths sparked a national outcry that was probably partly responsible for the retirement of a former KGB chief from the ruling Politburo. Writer and historian Ales Adamovich, a progressive member of the Congress of People's Deputies, said Gorbachev risks losing respect because of his disdain of the use of force. ``Can you achieve anything in this country with his character, mentality and psychology _ without a strong hand?'' he asked in an article printed in the Moscow News. ``He risks being misunderstood or just losing people's respect altogether. Remember, the people had respect for Stalin!'' ``Isn't there a risk that his personal democratism and non-violence could be regarded as his weakness _ in a country accustomed to a different style of leadership?'' Adamovich wrote. The deputy editor of the Moscow News, Vitaly Tretyakov, said the Soviet leader relies so heavily on compromise as a political tool that he sometimes blurs the line between what ultimately is acceptable and what is not. Armenians and Azerbaijanis have bitterly criticized Gorbachev's handling of the crisis that surrounds their conflicting claims to the Nagorno-Karabakh territory. World chess champion Garri Kasparov, a resident of Baku whose mother is Armenian, blamed Gorbachev's permissiveness for the bloodletting. ``Everyone can decide for themselves, but what can one think of a government that has permitted such horrendous events?'' he said in an interview with a Spanish newspaper after fleeing Baku. Another Armenian refugee from Baku, Nelya Azerburyan, interviewed in Moscow last week, said: ``Gorbachev never learned. Instead of all this glasnost, he should have studied the Central Asian people.'' At least one Western military observer in Moscow agrees that Gorbachev in the past has not acted forcefully enough. ``When you have people shooting at each other and killing each other with guns and other hardware, you have to disarm them,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``To do that, you have to kill some of them. If he's not willing to do that, he's not going to stop the fighting.'' It seems unlikely that the Soviet leader will respond with equal force to peaceful demands for independence. Gorbachev last month withstood a barrage of demands from conservative critics demanding he take tough action against the non-violent but determined drive by Lithuanians to restore the independence they lost to Stalin in 1940. The Communist Party chief argued Lithuanian leaders are taking their republic down a dead-end path. He flew there to face them and nationalist protesters, but he never threatened to use force to stop their independence drive.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Mark J. Porubcansky has covered Gorbachev and the Soviet Union's ethnic disputes from Moscow since February 1987.
