DOC.HEAD: Many Farmers Highly Skeptical About Restrictions On Chemical Use
DOC.TEXT: A study by the American Farmland Trust finds that many farmers favor crop methods to protect the environment but are highly skeptical of tougher federal restrictions on chemical use. The private, non-profit conservation group said Sunday that ``substantial numbers of farmrs across the country are interested in, and currently employing, a variety of environmentally benign, sustainable agricultural practices.'' But the report acknowledged that there are wide variations among farmers, depending on the kinds of crops involved and on geographic locations. For example, only 20 percent in one area used rotation plans while the majority in other areas followed the soil-saving practice. The project was based on personal interviews lasting for more than an hour with 489 farmers randomly selected in five major production areas in Butte County, Calif.; Whitman County, Wash.; Renville County, Minn.; Livingston County, Ill.; and Dooly County, Georgia. Questioners asked about methods used by the farmers in 1988, the most recently completed crop season, including their views on the potential environmental threats that might occur. The American Farmland Trust, which was founded in 1980, said it did not design the questions or interpret results ``with any hostility toward use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides.'' It said the study was undertaken in preparation for the 1990 farm bill debate under way in Congress. Environmental issues, including potential hazards of agricultural chemical pollution, are expected to have high priority. Over many years, report said, chemicals ``have brought great benefits to American agriculture and consumers'' and are ``essential for financial viability'' in most farming situations today. ``However, there is widespread evidence that an over-dependence on (chemical) use has developed and much effort is today devoted to seeking ways to enable farmers to economize on use of chemicals and fertilizer,'' the report said. The Agriculture Department was one of the sponsors of the study, although most of the financing came from private foundations. The USDA currently is developing LISA, or ``low-input, sustainable agriculture'' as an alternative to heavy use of crop chemicals and other practices that jeopardize soil and water resources. Some research findings show that many farmers ``apply excessive amounts of fertilizers or pesticides because they lack adequate information about what their fields really need or because they use very high applications as a form of insurance,'' the report said. ``Moreover,'' it added, ``in some situations, the threat or actuality of ground water or surface water pollution is high enough that a reduction in the use of chemicals may be necessary for health reasons.'' Crop rotation, long recognized as a way to build up soils, was used by a majority of the farmers in four of the five areas, with 54 percent to 82 percent employing the practice in 1988, the report said. The exception was in Butte County, Calif., where only 20 percent of those interviewed used rotations. Farmers were also asked whether they followed recommendations of fertilizer dealers or those of the federal-state cooperative extension service. ``Among interviewed farmers, there were many more clients of fertilizer dealers than there were takers of advice from cooperative extension service,'' the report said. Although 75 percent to 90 percent of the farmers favored changes in USDA commodity programs that would permit planting more acres in rotation without losing base acres used to compute federal crop benefits, most drew the line at a regulatory crackdown on excessive chemical use. One option would require farmers have an approved plan for managing pesticide use if crop chemicals were found in their well water. It was rejected in all five survey sites.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Services Struggle for New Image Under Reform Governments
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 15-16, `The head ... the SSS' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Pallagi's resignation. Pickup 17th pvs, ```The KGB...
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Democratic reforms have swept out the Old Guard in Eastern Europe, but its legacy lingers on in the foreign intelligence agencies that continue to spy at home and abroad, according to Western specialists. East European spies remain on the job, even though the security and espionage agencies they serve now face reorganization under new governments, the experts say. Authorities in East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Bulgaria say security forces have a place even in open societies. Traditionally these nations have combined internal security operations with foreign espionage. But the exact size and mandate of the surviving services _ as well as the fate of their foreign espionage networks _ is mostly obscured by the traditional lack of public accountability. One new development is that under democratic leaders, some cloak-and-dagger operations of the past, such as the 1978 assassination of Bulgarian writer and defector Georgi Markov, are being denounced and investigated. But nowhere have espionage agencies been totally disbanded. It is unclear what is happening to East Germany's formidable foreign espionage department, but West Germans have expressed fears that East German spies will use the open borders to slip into their country. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said East Germany, for one, continues its foreign espionage activities. ``East Germany would be well advised to pull back its agents even before a treaty on closer cooperation is signed,'' he said in a recent interview, referring to the comprehensive treaty that is supposed to be signed between the two states. ``There have been no indications that spying for East Berlin has stopped. The Stasi department in charge of espionage is functioning like it was during (deposed leader Erich) Honecker's time,'' the Munich magazine Bunte quoted Schaeuble as saying. East Germany's opposition has made the abolition of the secret service, or Stasi, the top issue in current opposition-government talks. Last week, an angry East Berlin mob stormed and looted the headquarters of the secret police. In Washington, CIA chief William Webster said in a speech Nov. 29, when only Romania was still untouched by reform, that Soviet bloc espionage had increased. ``Around the world, our stations are reporting more aggressive action, a more robust intelligence collection effort, more efforts to recruit our embassy and intelligence personnel than we have seen in a long time,'' Webster said. ``The stuff is changing so fast that people are working hard just to keep up with it,'' said one source at Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers, Europe. It is unclear whether the increasing independence emerging in East European politics will spill over into the intelligence agencies, which long have assisted the Soviet Union in its pursuit of Western secrets and technology. The former chief of Hungary's State Security Service, Brig.-Gen. Ferenc Pallagi, said in an interview published late last year that taking orders on intelligence activities from the Kremlin is ``a thing of the past.'' Both Pallagi and his deputy, Brig.-Gen. Joszef Horvath, resigned last week amid allegations the intelligence service spied on opposition groups in advance of Hungary's March parliamentary elections. Maj. Jozsef Vegvari, an officer in the security service, said Friday that as late as August there was a Soviet adviser attached to the Hungarian Interior Ministry, which runs the SSS. ``The KGB is active in Hungary for sure,'' he said. Vegvari faces charges for revealing information to the political opposition on surveillance by his own service. Romania's internal secret police, the Securitate, was dismantled after the December revolution, but the former chief of the Romanian intelligence service, Ion Pacepa, predicted Romania's espionage will increase. ``They will steal technology, and now they will steal it much more easily, because people in the West will want to help the Romanians and will give them technology, and they will give it to Moscow,'' said Pacepa, who defected to the United States a decade ago. Under the new non-Communist dominated Czechoslovak government, Interior Minister Richard Sacher announced last week that the STB, the secret service charged with gathering information on dissidents, had been disbanded. However, in an interview with the Czechoslovak news agency CTK, Sacher said some Interior Ministry departments ``needed for the defense of the state will also be needed in independent Czechoslovakia.'' He did not specify what their job would be. In Warsaw, sources within the Solidarity-led government have told The Associated Press they are trying to strip Poland's Embassy in Moscow of diplomats who worked for the Soviet intelligence apparatus. Still relatively intact among the East bloc services is Bulgaria's State Security, known by its Bulgarian initials DS. After the November ouster of hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, the reform-minded leadership promised to publicize more information on intelligence activities, as well as investigate the murder by poison-tipped umbrella of Markov, the Bulgarian dissident author killed in London in 12 years ago. There has long been speculation that the orders to kill Markov came from Bucharest. The scandal forced the resignation last week of Jozsef Horvath, head of the Internal Security Service. But although Bulgaria's new leadership is trying to cast off its Stalinist image, the Bulgarian domestic surveillance and foreign intelligence gathering operations appear to be continuing. ``What we know is that almost every Bulgarian who is doing some job abroad is an agent or informant of DS, including diplomats, journalists, and trade functionaries,'' said one Bulgarian exile who monitors intelligence affairs and spoke in exchange for anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Schools, Jobs for Women Sought to Hold Down Population
DOC.TEXT: More schools and more jobs for women would do most to hold down massive growth in the numbers of people in the Third World, a report by the Population Institute said Sunday. It found a link between ignorance and overpopulation. ``The population explosion is no longer a prediction. It's already here,'' according to the institute, an advocacy group on this issue. The study noted that last year, the world's population increased by over 90 million people. Rich countries like the United States have ignorant people as well as the Third World, though they are fewer. The report said that among people in some industrial countries, one in 10 is ``functionally illiterate.'' That is, they can read and write some, but they can not follow printed instructions or write a simple letter. The report said about 900 million of the world's 5.5 billion people cannot read, and that almost two out of every three illiterates are women. ``In Sudan women with no formal education had, on average, 6.5 children,'' it said. ``But Sudanese women with four to six years of school averaged five children and those with seven or more years of school averaged 3.4 children.'' ``In Mexico ... uneducated women had an average of eight children but women with seven or more years of education averaged 2.7,'' the report said. The study reported that women who get only one or two years of school tend to have more surviving childrern rather than fewer. It suggested that was because even a little education helps a mother keep her babies alive. Women who stay at school longer get married later and know more about contraceptives. The study was prepared by Harold N. Burdett, the institute's director of information, and Werner Fornos, its president. ``Nations that have opened up the schoolhouse and the workplace to women have experienced uniform declines in their fertility rates,'' Fornos said. At a news conference, he praised South Korea for its program to give all girls eight years of school and to emphasize the textile industry as a big employer of women. ``In Bangladesh ... high fertility rates have been slow to decline and many girls are already married by the age of 13,'' the report said. Bangladesh, where the average person has an income of $170 a year, is one of the world's poorest countries. The report continued: ``By contrast, South Korea, a country of 42 million people which has made significant economic strides in recent years, has a 1.4 percent annual growth rate _ the lowest of any major developing nation in Asia _ and the average age at first marriage has risen from 17.8 years several decades ago to approximately 23 years today.'' The World Bank put the average income in South Korea at $3,530 in 1988. Fornos also cited Mexico for encouraging industries along the border that make goods for the United States. He said there are about 900, ``some of them as big as football fields,'' where women do 85 percent of the work on such jobs as assembling computer parts. He found 30 countries in the Third World in this kind of restructuring: from Zimbabwe, trying like South Korea to keep girls in school for eight years, to Indonesia, where ``Mothers' Clubs'' help women care for their babies and learn new skills. Fornos warned of what he called the ``aspiration bomb'' _ the danger of educated young people turning to crime because they cannot find jobs. He said he had seen the results in violent gangs of young graduates now worrying Kenya, where authorities have pushed education hard. The report pointed to Peru. ``The anger and frustration of young Peruvians who made sacrifices to obtain an education only to end up unemployed and disillusioned have resulted in drug addiction, delinquency and radical politics for many,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Alcohol, Drug Use Decline, Activism Increases
DOC.TEXT: College freshmen are becoming more conservative about drugs and crime but more liberal about legalized abortion, environmental issues and student activism, according to a study released Sunday. The 24th annual survey of entering college freshmen conducted jointly by UCLA's Higher Education Research Institute and the American Council on Education found an ``abrupt change'' in student attitudes about legalized abortions. Support for legalized abortion, which had remained fairly stable _ between 53 percent and 59 percent _ since 1977, jumped sharply between the 1988 and 1989 surveys, from 57 percent to 64.7 percent. ``An abrupt change in student attitudes of this magnitude in just one year is most unusual,'' said Alexander W. Astin, professor of higher education at UCLA's Graduate School of Education and the survey's director. He added that ``it may well reflect the students' growing concern about the current Supreme Court's position on this highly charged topic.'' The survey found the environment was the top concern, with six out of every seven of those questioned agreeing that ``the federal government is not doing enough to control environmental pollution.'' And, 78.2 percent of the students endorsed greater governmental efforts to control handguns _ a new question asked for the first time in 1989. Support for abolition of the death penalty continued its sharp decline, as did student use of drugs and alcohol. The survey found a growing tendency toward greater student activism. ``While student attitudes seem to be moving in a `conservative' direction on the issues of drugs and crime, their views on most other issues are changing in a decidedly `liberal' direction,' said Astin. The 1989 national survey is based on the responses of 216,362 students at 403 of the nation's two- and four-year colleges and universities. These data have been statistically adjusted to reflect the responses of the 1.6 million first-time, full-time students entering college as freshmen in the fall of 1989. Key findings were: _Only 21.3 percent oppose the death penalty, compared to 23.0 in 1988 and 57.6 percent in 1971. _The percentage of freshmen who reported drinking beer dropped to 60.3 percent, down from 65.3 percent in 1988 and 75.2 percent in 1981. _Freshmen who reported drinking wine or liquor dropped to 60.7 percent in 1989, compared to 66.7 percent in 1988. _The percentage of students who agree that ``marijuana should be legalized'' reached another all-time low of 16.7 percent, down from 19.3 percent in 1988 and 52.9 percent in 1977. _The percent of students who agree that employers should be allowed to require drug testing of employees and job applicants jumped sharply from 71 percent to 77.8 percent between 1988 and 1989. According to the survey, the share of freshmen who participated in organized demonstrations during the year prior to entering college reached a high of 36.7 percent, which is greater than the percentages observed during the last 1960s. At the same time, the percentage of freshmen who said that there is a ``very good chance'' that they will participate in student protests or demonstrations in college also reached an all-time high of 6.3 percent, up from 5.4 percent in 1988 and 4.7 percent in 1967. An all-time high of 44.1 percent of students reported that it is a ``very important'' goal for them to ``influence social values.'' This figure is up from 36 percent in 1987 and 31.1 percent in 1982. For the fifth consecutive year, student concern for the environment increased with 86.3 percent of freshmen wanting better federal efforts to control pollution, compared with 83.9 percent in 1988 and 80.9 percent in 1987. The survey showed that student interest in becoming involved in programs to clean up the environment also increased, with 26.1 percent of the 1989 college freshmen saying that this is a ``very important'' life goal, compared with only 15.9 percent in 1986. ``These trends show not only that most students want more governmental action in the environmental field, but that increasing numbers of them are willing to become personally involved in the effort,''said Astin.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Portrayed Himself As Anti-Drug Crusader
With AM-Barry Bjt
DOC.TEXT: District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry, seeking treatment after his arrest on federal cocaine charges, often tried to convey the image of a tough-on-drugs executive while disputing reports he personally used narcotics. On a radio call-in show Sept. 17, 1987, Barry criticized a federal prosecutor's decision to dismiss up to 400 drug cases because the police officers who investigated them were suspected of corruption. ``My view is that the judge ought to decide whether or not the case ought to be thrown out or not prosecuted,'' Barry said. ``We're letting people who are poisoning our community almost really go free. It sends the wrong signal to that community.'' When traces of cocaine were discovered in the hotel room of former city employee Charles Lewis after Barry visited him in December 1988, the mayor said through a spokesman: ``I would never knowingly associate with anybody using drugs or dealing with drugs. Under no circumstances would I associate with anybody doing this.'' On March 14, 1989, Barry and other city officials met with William J. Bennett, head of the national drug control policy office, and the mayor said that ``he and I agreed ... there will be no quick fixes.'' He said he told Bennett the city needed more money to expand drug treatment programs and stem drug-related killings. Nine days later, he told the National Press Club: ``Drugs are the problem, not Marion Barry. I urge the media to be fair.'' Talking about the growing crime wave, including record numbers of homicides, he said: ``For the most part, the targeted killings and drug activity take place in a small section of the city. Except for the killings, Washington has one of the lowest crime rates in the country. ``Congress is safe; everyone is safe. I hope to come back here next year and tell you Washington is safer than ever before.'' In May 1989, after his administration came under fire for failing to stem the increase in drug-related violence in the city, the mayor arrived at an alleged crack house with eviction papers in his hand and television cameras by his side, surprising 16 people in the apartment and federal agents who had arrived an hour later to serve a search warrant. Barry directed city workers to nail the apartment's windows and doors shut, but Treasury Department agents tore down the plywood boards when they arrived with the warrant. No one was arrested in either raid. On April 4, 1989, testifying before the Senate appropriations subcommittee on the District of Columbia, Barry outlined a $102 million plan for stemming drug-related violence, but Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., dismissed it as a ``Chamber of Commerce document'' and accused the mayor of glossing over the city's problems. ``If I were to judge you on the job you're doing with drugs, and I were given a vote, I wouldn't vote for you,'' Kerrey said. ``In the absence of a community committed to solving the problem, no amount of money would help.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Quincy Jones was awarded the French Legion of Honor Sunday for his musical contribution as a trumpeter, composer, arranger and record producer. In presenting the medal to Jones, Thierry de Beauce, secretary of state for international cultural relations, called Jones ``a man who reconciles the rhythms of rock, jazz and bop.'' Jones, 56, is well known on both sides of the Atlantic. He first came to France in 1953 at age 19 with Lionel Hampton's orchestra. His career since then includes collaboration with some of America and France's greatest artists _Aretha Franklin, George Benson, Jacques Brel, Michel Legrand, Miles Davis, Ray Charles and Charles Aznavour, to name a few. As a record producer, Jones was responsible for two of the most successful albums of the 1980s _ Michael Jackson's ``Thriller'' and ``Bad.'' After six years of dedicating himself to producing, Jones released his own album, ``Back on the Block,'' which has risen to 16th place on U.S. charts since its December release.

Former ``Mayflower Madam'' Sydney Biddle Barrows has apologized for a paragraph in her new intimate etiquette book that suggests dinner guests be told if someone with AIDS is at the table. The publisher, Doubleday, said in a press release Saturday that many have complained that the passage in the book ``Mayflower Manners'' is insensitive. ``Most people will know that they cannot contract the disease by being seated at a dinner table with a carrier,'' Miss Barrows wrote. ``But it is a courtesy to all to let them know ahead of time.'' Miss Barrows said in the release, ``My advice was intended to protect the feelings of such a guest from the ignorance of those who might inadvertently bring up a subject, causing discomfort to the guest. I intended no other meaning or inference.'' She said the passage would be deleted in future printings. The book by Ellis Weiner and Miss Barrows is described by the publisher as ``a satirical and tongue-in-cheek advice book.'' Miss Barrows, a member of a prominent socialite family who ran a high-price escort service, pleaded guilty in 1985 to a misdemeanor charge of promoting prostitution and paid a $5,000 fine. She was dubbed the ``Mayflower Madam'' because she traces some of her ancestors to the group that came over on the Mayflower.

Despite his run-ins with General Motors Corp. after the giant automaker bought his Electronic Data Systems, Dallas billionaire Ross Perot said he did not revel in a new movie's stinging criticism of GM Chairman Roger Smith. ``I get no sense of comfort in foreseeing what is happening to GM,'' Perot told the Dallas Times Herald after seeing ``Roger & Me,'' which documents the impact of GM layoffs on Flint, Mich. ``The film was hard on Roger. He's really a bright and creative guy,'' Perot said. Perot said the movie is a must-see film because it vividly shows what could happen to U.S. business if companies do not change their approach to competition from the Far East. ``When you watch `Roger & Me' and you're seeing American companies deteriorate, remember that you're looking at the nuking of our tax base,'' Perot said.

Michael Landon, who played Little Joe Cartwright in the long-running TV series ``Bonanza,'' can kick up his cowboy boots at his new ranch that took a decade to build. Landon, who also starred in ``Little House on the Prairie'' and ``Highway to Heaven,'' traded an oceanfront residence at celebrity-saturated Malibu Colony for a ranch estate in bucolic Bonsall Canyon. The actor-director-producer bought the property 10 years ago as a place to relax with his family. Landon, 52, has seven grown children from two previous marriages and has two young children with his current wife, Cindy. ``They didn't anticipate that it would become their home, but as we designed the plans, it developed from a ranch to an estate that has the old Bel-Air or Pasadena look,'' said architect Robert Earl. Industry sources estimate the value of the ranch at $7 million, the Los Angeles Times reported.

No joke, the Mississippi Senate has named a state highway for humorist Jerry Clower, a native son. ``I'm overwhelmed, stunned _ it just elates me,'' Clower said from his Liberty home after the Senate voted Friday to name a stretch of Mississippi Highway 24 between Liberty and McComb for him. ``I was raised on Highway 24 when it was a dirt road. I saw them pave that road in the '30s and '40s. I've hitchhiked on it. I've rode the school bus on it,'' Clower said. ``I just want all of the Legislature to know how much I appreciate it. I'll make sure I walk circumspectly from now on.'' Clower, a Grand Ole Opry regular who has recorded 19 humor albums, often uses Liberty as the setting for his comic stories.

Former Dallas Cowboys Coach Tom Landry said his singing on a television commercial doesn't mean he's packing for Nashville. ``They spent about three months twisting my arm before I decided to do that,'' Landry said of his ads promoting Quality Inns, the motel chain. In the commercial, he sings, ``Mama, don't let your babies grow up to be _ Redskins.'' Then he smiles deviously and asks if viewers thought he was going to say ``Cowboys.'' ``About the only place I sing is in church,'' Landry told the Dallas Times Herald. ``And my wife said she's glad I get a lot of help there.'' ``I don't think Willie Nelson should ever feel threatened by my singing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Ambassador Says Washington Would Hear No Evil About Ceausescu
Laserphoto RA1
DOC.TEXT: He tried to tell Washington, says David Funderburk, but during four years as ambassador to Romania he couldn't convince anyone that Nicolae Ceausescu was a murderous tyrant undeserving of American favors. ``It was like beating my head against a brick wall,'' Funderburk said in an interview from his home in Buies Creek, N.C., where he now runs an anti-communist foundation. ``We reported what was really happening and the whole litany of horrors that Ceausescu was carrying out, but my reports weren't reaching the top people and they certainly weren't being factored into our relationship.'' Funderburk, 45, a former college teacher fluent in Romanian, says he knows why: when President Reagan appointed him in 1981, he was regarded by the State Department as a protege of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the department's nemesis. Now, of course, the world knows that Funderburk's descriptions were accurate. Ceausescu ran a police state. His people were virtually starved while Romanian farm products were sent abroad. Women were penalized if they refused to have babies. Clergymen and opponents were killed. Every typewriter had to be registered. The United States, Funderburk said, is still following a wrongheaded policy in Romania, backing Ceausescu's successor, communist Ion Iliescu, head of the National Salvation Front government. ``We ought to be offering our moral support to the outmanned non-communists,'' he said. During the Nixon Administration, the United States had seen a streak of independence in Ceausescu. To encourage other communists to inch away from Moscow, Romania was given most favored nation trade status and Ceausescu was showered with attention. Presidents Nixon and Ford and other high officials visited, offering praise for Ceausescu's ``courage.'' Nixon and President Carter lavishly welcomed him to Washington. Funderburk said George Bush, who was then vice president; Alexander M. Haig, who was secretary of state; and businessmen who wanted to trade with Romania ``trekked over to Bucharest to do homage to Ceausescu.'' He said he asked the visitors to press Ceausescu to honor his human rights commitments but they ``had been told to just ignore Funderburk.'' Career diplomat Francis B. Corry, assigned as Funderburk's deputy, confirmed that the ambassador was persona non grata in the State Deparment. ``He had the reputation _ not entirely deserved _ of being a protege of Jesse Helms,'' said Corry, who has since retired. Corry added that ``Helms' relationship with the Department of State being what it was, there was little David Funderburk could do to help his relationship with the department.'' As for the kid gloves policy toward Ceausescu, Corry said: ``Was the policy of differentiation, which was conceived in Kissingerian times, wise? An argument could be made either way. ``We never got a hell of a lot of true independence from Ceausescu. How could they be independent with a 1,500-kilometer border with the Soviet Union?'' On the other hand, Corry said, ``I felt _ and in this I agreed with the department _ that having extended most favored nation status, pulling it back would remove whatever leverage we had with Ceausescu.'' The Romanian dictator had demonstrated a degree of maverick behavior. He maintained ties with West Germany, refused to break relations with Israel after the Six-Day War, refused to boycott the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, and declined to back Soviet interventions in Czechoslovakia and Afghanistan. Moreover, tens of thousands of Jews were allowed to leave. It later turned out Ceausescu had received thousands of dollars from Israel for each emigre. Funderburk argued Ceausescu's independence was a ploy. ``Behind the scenes he was collaborating with the Soviets'' and sharing the Western techology he was allowed to import, he advised Washington. Unable to budge the State Department, Funderburk said he used his influence with conservatives to arrange a 1983 Oval Office meeting with Ronald Reagan. ``The president seemed sympathetic and surprised, but unless he heard the same message day after day he wasn't about to act against his own secretary of state,'' Funderurk said. Thus, the ``groveling'' continued. The department, furious that he had gone around channels, undertook to force him out as ambassador, Funderburk said. Finally, in 1985, he quit in frustration, he said. Funderburk said he remains appalled at U.S. policy. ``We rushed in with a new ambassador and recognized the provisional government. Most of those characters are people who worked with Ceausescu. Here we are propping up a communist government composed of people the people hate. We don't learn anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope to Visit Czechoslovakia in Second Half of April
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will visit Czechoslovakia in the second half of April, and diplomatic relations between Prague and the Vatican could be restored before then, Czechoslovak officials said Sunday. It will be John Paul's first voyage to an Eastern European country other than his native Poland, marking another breakthrough in ties between the Vatican and Soviet bloc nations that have shed their hard-line Communist leaders. A Czechoslovak government delegation issued the invitation to the pope Saturday on behalf of President Vaclav Havel and Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, the archbishop of Prague and the Roman Catholic primate of Czechoslovakia. The Vatican reported Saturday that the pope had accepted the invitation but said only that the trip would take place sometime before the Czechoslovak elections in June. Jan Carnogursky, first deputy prime minister and head of the government delegation, told a news conference the pope will visit Prague, Velehrad and Bratislava in the last half of April. He said final details were still being worked out and he could not confirm some published reports in Italy and Hungary that the trip would begin April 21. Carnogursky said the government invited the pope as a ``great moral authority, as head of the Catholic faith which has millions of followers in Czechoslovakia, and as a major personality in today's world.'' ``All three aspects symbolize the dimension of the changes realized in Czechoslovakia recently,'' he said. Carnogursky said the new Czechoslovak government wants to re-establish diplomatic relations with the Holy See ``as soon as possible'' and that the pope and Vatican Secretary of State Agostino Casaroli agreed. Ties were broken by Czechoslovakia in 1949. The official said an announcement on resumption of diplomatic ties could come soon after the appointment of new Roman Catholic bishops in March. Five of the country's 13 bishoprics are vacant. The former Communist regime blocked some of the Vatican's appointments, but Carnogursky said the new government would pose ``no obstacles or problems'' to the naming of new bishops. The Czechoslovak Parliament on Tuesday will abolish a 1949 decree requiring government approval of bishops' appointments, thus giving the Holy See a free hand to name its own candidates, the officials said. ``The intention of the new democratic government is that there be freedom of religion,'' said Josef Hromadka, deputy prime minister with responsibility for religious affairs. As recently as two years ago, the pope decried the ``sorry state'' of the church in Czechoslovakia, where an estimated 60 percent of the 15 million people are Roman Catholics. But improvements were made last year, even before the opposition victory that ended the Communists' 41-year domination of the government. The Vatican is also expected to re-estalish relations with Hungary shortly. The pope is scheduled to travel to Hungary in September 1991. Last July, Poland became the first Warsaw Pact country to restore full ties with the Holy See.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Eyes Campaign Finance Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Stung by the loss of two top House Democrats and the problems of five senators embroiled in a savings and loan furor, congressional leaders are weighing a substantial revamping of campaign finance laws. A bipartisan House task force is at work on the problem and Senate leaders seem determined to watch what the House does before acting on their own. Complicating prospects for passage is the fact that all 435 members of the House and a third of the Senate are up for re-election this year. Still, Speaker Thomas S. Foley was able on Sunday to predict passage of a reform bill in the House. ``I think it's going to happen in this session ... at least in the House,'' the Washington Democrat said on NBC's ``Meet the Press.'' Congress historically has been reluctant to legislate in this politically touchy area, especially in an election year, and this issue has been bogged down in partisan argument since early 1988. Yet, pressure is building, thanks largely to the political brouhaha surrounding Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. and the five senators to whom he gave $1.3 million in campaign and other contributions in his fight with savings and loan regulators. The five senators _ Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John McCain, R-Ariz., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich. _ are now subjects of Senate Ethics Committee inquiries for interceding with S&L regulators on Keating's behalf. This political firestorm, which ignited last year after House Speaker Jim Wright and Democratic Whip Tony Coelho resigned amid ethics problems, has given impetus to the fight for campaign finance reform. ``With the exception of Watergate, I can't remember a single incident that has educated people all over the country on the real price that is paid in a campaign financing system that allows money to be used for buying influence,'' said Fred Wertheimer, head of the self-styled citizens lobby, Common Cause. A 21-member bipartisan House task force has been instructed by Foley and Republican Leader Robert H. Michel of Illinois to have a bill ready as soon as possible after Congress returns Tuesday. No specific date was set, but congressional officials working on the package said the clear intent of Foley's directions was to have a bipartisan package prepared for a vote in March. In the Senate, Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine and GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas discussed setting up a similar task force after Congress adjourned last month. While Senate leaders want to see what the House does first before producing a package of their own, the leader of the last failed reform effort, Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., is working with McCain _ one of the ``Keating Five'' _ on a bipartisan proposal. Wertheimer's organization, which advocates spending limits and federal financing of campaigns, filed the initial complaint with the ethics panel last October. This forced the inquiries into the five senators' intervention with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on behalf of Keating's now-collapsed Lincoln Savings and Loan, based in Irvine, Calif. All five senators have denied they intervened with the bank board in the Lincoln case because of Keating's contributions. The five said they often intercede with federal agencies on behalf of constituents who are not contributors. Just how much ``reform'' will be in a campaign finance bill that can win both Democratic and Republican support _ and not pose a serious threat to the careers of incumbent lawmakers _ is in doubt. Common Cause has dropped its demand for public financing of the type used in presidential campaigns since the passage of the last significant campaign money law in 1974 following the Watergate scandal. Public financing and voluntary spending ceilings, wanted by Democrats but opposed by Republicans, stymied the last reform effort in 1987-88. After Congress adjourned with the Keating controversy fresh in its mind, Michel told the National Press Club he would give ``personal consideration to some type of cap,'' indicating a softening in the GOP's historic opposition to spending ceilings. Instead of offering government campaign dollars to candidates who abide by voluntary spending ceilings _ compulsory caps are illegal under a Supreme Court decision _ Democrats are talking of using discount mail and TV advertising rates as a carrot for compliance. So-called ``soft money'' contributions, which go to national and state party organizations or independent groups and foundations utilized by members of Congress, remain a major stumbling block. Most of those contributions do not now have to be reported to the Federal Election Commission and only a few states, such as California, require their disclosure. Keating contributed $85,000 each to Republican and Democratic party committees in California, where Lincoln's 29 thrift branches operated. Republican members of Congress, who rely on their party more than Democrats for raising election money, are opposed to any measure that would curb that ability. But they want to restrict business, trade association and labor PACs that increasingly are becoming the biggest source of cash for incumbent Democrats. ``There's always support for campaign finance reform in general, but when it comes down to specifics, that's where everything breaks down,'' said Ross Baker, a campaign finance expert at Rutgers University. Until Republicans get over their distaste for public financing and Democrats give up their love affair with PACs, he said, the best reform would be requiring more disclosure. ``The ultimate sanction against a candidate who takes too much money _ or money from the wrong people _ is that an opponent can use it as an issue,'' he said. ``That's the great dagger hanging over the heads of those five senators.'' None of the ``Keating Five,'' however, is among the 33 senators up for re-election this year.

DOC.HEAD: Bureaucratic Process Impedes Distribution For Therapeautic Use
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: For the past 13 years, Robert Randall has made regular trips to a pharmacy to get, legally and free, what many others buy on the street at the risk of arrest _ marijuana. Randall was the first person allowed by the federal government to use the drug for medical purposes, in his case as a treatment for the blinding eye disease glaucoma, under what is termed a ``compassionate'' protocol. Others have received permission to use marijuana legally for controlling nausea caused by anti-cancer drugs, for pain relief and for controlling muscle spasms in people with multiple sclerosis. But Randall says it's easier for patients to get the drug in an illegal street sale than through the legitimate but time-consuming and bureaucratic process that allows government-grown marijuana to be distributed free by prescription as an experimental drug. ``It's an extraordinary process to engage in. It stretches the word `compassionate' to the limit,'' Randall said an interview last week at his Washington home. ``I've watched one or two people go blind while waiting.'' Only four other people _ two with glaucoma, one with cancer and one with AIDS _ currently are receiving marijuana from the government, said Randall, president of the Alliance for Cannabis Therapeutics. The Food and Drug Administration did not know how many people have gotten marijuana under a ``compassionate'' protocol, but a spokesman said at least two dozen protocols _ some covering groups of patients _ have been approved since Randall's in 1976. Most of the protocols now are inactive, either because patients have died or have switched to other drugs. The process starts with a request from a physician for authorization to prescribe marijuana for a patient. If the FDA approves the physician's plans, the request goes to the National Institute for Drug Abuse, which is responsible for growing the drug on a Mississippi farm. After NIDA certifies it has a supply of the drug, the request goes to the Drug Enforcement Administration, which must assure tight control over distribution of the drug. Randall's group and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws went to court again on Friday to try to force the DEA to change marijuana's status as a Schedule I drug, which is available only for research, to a Schedule II drug, which would make it available for patient use, as morphine and cocaine are. A DEA administrative law judge in 1988 recommended that marijuana be reclassified, but DEA Administrator John Lawn rejected the recommendation Dec. 29, saying the judge ignored the scientific evidence. Randall said Lawn's action ignores the pain of the ill solely to ``promote his political agenda,'' the war against illegal drugs. ``For me, marijuana is just another medication,'' Randall said, adding that the only effect he gets from the drug is therapeutic _ it reduces the pressure inside his eye, helping him retain his vision. Randall, who turns 42 on Tuesday, gets by prescription 300 neatly rolled marijuana cigarettes a month and smokes 10 of them each day. He said he hasn't gotten high from the drug for years, partly because of the low potency of government-grade marijuana. The American Academy of Ophthalmology Committee on Drugs says that while marijuana can lower intraocular pressure, there is no evidence the drug can safely and effectively lower it enough to prevent optic nerve damage. Besides the long-term lung damage that can occur from smoking the drug, short-term side effects include euphoria, low blood pressure and eye dryness, the committee said. The panel said long-term studies are needed. Dr. Keith Green, a regents professor of ophthalmology at the Medical College of Georgia in Augusta, Ga., who has studied marijuana, said better drugs than marijuana are available for glaucoma patients. ``If this were a worthwhile venture, there would be much greater utilization and recommendation of its use by the physicians in the (ophthalmology) community,'' Green said. But Dr. Ivan Silverberg, a medical oncologist in San Francisco, said that among cancer and AIDS patients, ``there's still a lot of interest'' in using marijuana to control nausea and pain. ``Patients use it all the time,'' he said. ``It's very common in the Bay Area,'' among older as well as younger patients. He added that while ``this is not the greatest drug known to man,'' it is ``the most effective of the out-patient drugs'' for controlling nausea because patients can get relief in a matter of seconds without having to swallow a pill and keep it down for 30 to 90 minutes. Also, smoking allows a patient better dose control because they can stop when they get relief, he said. Silverberg said he's not willing to go through the steps needed to get permission to prescribe marijuana for patients because the government's process is too time-consuming and patients who want it can easily get it. ``I don't prescribe it, I don't smoke it, and I don't have a reputation as a pot doctor,'' Silverberg said. But, he added, ``if I think a patient is going to be nauseated, we'll talk about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Demand End to Vestiges of Communist Regime
LaserPhoto BUC1
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 students rallied in Bucharest on Sunday to demand an end to the last vestiges of Communist rule _ from incompetent professors to the ideological institute that trained past officials. The protesters outside Bucharest University booed the mention of the former Communist Youth Union and chanted ``Liberty!'' and ``Solidarity!'' as a string of speakers called for students to become a force in building a new, democratic Romania. Loud applause greeted Eduard Cucu, a student from the northern city of Iasi, as he announced: ``We have organized to get rid of incompetent teachers and the teachers who told the security forces what was going on.'' Last week, students at Bucharest's sprawling Polytechnic University began a campaign to rid the student body of police informers and professors who obtained their posts through party affiliation. The Bucharest University administration is considering whether to fire Mihaela Ceausescu, a niece of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, from her post as a professor of Russian. It was common under the Ceausescu regime for doctorates to be awarded on the basis of party standing rather than academic qualifications. The students repeatedly broke into chants of ``Down with the incompetents!'' during the more than two-hour demonstration. The loudest jeering and booing came when philosophy student Daniel Oghina spoke out against the Stefan Gheorghiu Social and Political Academy, which trained many of the officials in Ceausescu's dreaded Securitate secret police force. The academy served as the ideological training school for all Ceausescu's officials and was a necessary gate to further advancement in both the party and the government under the dictator. Ceausescu was elected by firing squad Christmas Day. Oghina said authorities want to keep the institute going and give it the ironic ``new title of the Free Academy of Stefan Gheorghiu.'' Gheorghiu was a pre-war Communist leader in Romania. ``They're repeating the same structures of the old regime,'' he said. The interim government's plans for the academy could not immediately be determined. Some of the speakers also complained of the actions of the governing National Salvation Front, which took over after the revolution that ousted Ceausescu. One sign held by demonstrators read ``Down with the Securitate people in the new government.'' ``We want the provisional government to be formed of people who will represent the Romanian people,'' student Dan Josef told the crowd, which blocked Nicolae Balcescu Boulevard, one of the main streets of Bucharest. Dumitru Mazilu, vice president of the National Salvation Front, has come under fire since the revolution for reportedly holding a colonel's rank in the Securitate during the 1970s. After falling from favor in the Ceausescu regime, he became one of the nation's most internationally known dissidents. The National Salvation Front has so far defended Mazilu, pointing to his conversion to a human rights advocate and critic of the Ceausescu regime. Sunday's demonstration came a month after bloody fighting in Bucharest, some of it along the same boulevard where the students gathered. After a moment of silence for the thousands of people who died in the revolution, the crowd held their hands up in victory signs and sang the formerly banned song ``Awake Romania,'' a nationalist song dating from the Turkish domination of the nation, which ended in the late 19th century. The song starts ``Awake Romania from your mortal sleep that the barbarians and tyrants put you in ... We'd rather die in glorious battle than become slaves again.'' Most of the demonstration, however, was made up of speakers calling on students to unify. Several French students also spoke to the crowd, raising chants of ``Vive la Roumanie!'' and ``Vive la France.!' One French student, who did not give his name, told the Romanians: ``You gave us a lesson in democracy ... For this, we thank you.''

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party to Band with Opposition Groups in South Korea
DOC.TEXT: = SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ President Roh Tae-woo has agreed to dissolve his governing party to create a new conservative party in alliance with two moderate opposition groups, top politicians said Sunday. Roh also has agreed to revise the constitution to replace the country's present presidential system of government with a parliamentary system to be headed by a prime minister, the officials said. The plan is designed to break a deadlock in the legislature, which is controlled by three opposition parties whose strong rivalries have prevented them from working together against the governing party. The plan would also dwarf the nation's most radical opposition party, the Party for Peace and Democracy, and its charismatic leader, Kim Dae-jung. In addition, the parliamentary system would allow Roh the chance to remain in power as prime minister after his five-year term as president ends in 1993. Those familiar with the agreement said it will be formalized at a meeting Monday between Roh, Kim Young-sam, leader of the No. 2 opposition group, the Reunification Democratic Party, and Kim Jong-pil, a former premier who heads the No. 3 opposition group, the New Democratic Republican Party. Kim Jong-pil said the three-way talks will formally announce the creation of a new conservative party. ``Everything has been set for the new party,'' he told a meeting of party lawmakers Sunday night. He said five delegates from each party will begin working together Tuesday to prepare for the new party, expected to emerge about a month later. An official in the governing Democratic Justice Party said that the three parties agreed during weeks of private discussions to create a new party and to change the constitution to adopt a Cabinet system of government. They also agreed that the new party to be formed will try to comprise ``all liberal democratic forces,'' said the official, who requested anonymity. Insiders said Roh agreed to the realignment, initiated by the two opposition parties, after Kim Young-sam reversed himself and agreed to support changing from a presidential system to a cAbinet system of government. The new party could be a serious setback for Kim Dae-jung, leader of the hard-line opposition Party for Peace and Democracy. His party would be dwarfed by the new party, thus limiting his chances of coming to power. The governing party may have agreed to the realignment because it has no clear successor to Roh, whose single fiver-year term expires in 1993. Governing party officials have made it clear they hope to imitate Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party, which has long remained in power under a Cabinet system of government. Roh's governing party has been in an uncomfortable situation since it lost a parliamentary majority in the 1988 general elections. The three main opposition parties have a combined majority in the 299-member National Assembly but intense rivalry has made it difficult for them to cooperate. The new party to be formed is expected to have a collective leadership with Roh serving as a ceremonial head. A merger of the three parties will also assure it of a two-third majority required in parliament to introduce the constitutional revision. Insiders said the new party would push a constitutional revision during the term of the current assembly, which expires in May, 1992. A constitutional draft adopted in Parliament must be approved in a national referendum. Even if a new constitution is adopted, Roh's term, which expires in February 1993, is expected to be completed by him.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Threaten Boycott Over U.S. AIDS Policy
DOC.TEXT: Health Minister Claude Evin has added his name to the list of prominent Europeans threatening to boycott an AIDS meeting in San Francisco unless the U.S. Congress changes a law they say ``stupidly discriminates'' against AIDS victims. Evin, in a letter to World Health Organization secretary-general Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, condemned the U.S. immigration law that he said ``discriminates on the basis of health.'' He said he will not attend the huge Sixth International Conference on AIDS to be held June 20-24 in San Francisco ``in the absence of guarantees respecting individual liberty.'' Evins' letter was dated Jan. 13, and its contents were carried Friday by the news agency Agence France-Presse. WHO is one of the sponsors of the prestigious meeting, which each year draws doctors, researchers, health officials and representatives from many of the world's most respected health organizations. At least 16 organizations from France, Scandinavia, Britain and elsewhere have announced that they plan to boycott the meeting unless the U.S. government changes a policy that prohibits people suffering AIDS from entering the United States without a special waiver. Those granted the waiver have their passports stamped with a permanent number indicating they are infected with the HIV virus that causes the deadly disease. Critics complain the law violates an individual's right to privacy, punishes the honest, makes the individual vulnerable to discrimination at home, and is not justified on public health grounds. ``To us Europeans, this seems a profoundly shocking policy, especially in light of America's well-publicized belief in freedom and respect for human rights. It stupidly discriminates and deeply contradicts America's stated values,'' said Henri Maurel, spokesman for the French group APARTS, which assists people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Since the early 1950s, the United States has required that people requesting an entry visa declare if they are infected with contagious diseases such as syphillis, leprosy or tuberculosis. The question has not been uniformly applied and was not asked at all of travelers coming from countries that do not require visas, like Canada. In 1987, under a measure introduced by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., AIDS was added to the list. Critics claim that immigration officials then went on a campaign to ferret out people suffering from AIDS, even going through luggage looking for medicine used to treat the disease. ``Our end is not to stay away from this important meeting,'' said Manon Fournerie, spokeswoman for France-AIDS. ``What we want is to call attention to the problem and for the United States to change this discriminatory law.'' Protests of the law have come from the international societies of the Red Cross, the World Health Organization, the World Federation of Hemophilia and the National Commission on AIDS. The commission makes recommendations to the U.S. Congress and president to develop a consistent national policy on fighting AIDS. ``The way you deal with AIDS is by educating the population, not by sealing off the border,'' said Dr. June E. Osborn, head of the National Commission on AIDS and chairman of the University of Michigan School of Public Health. Osborn, in a telephone interview, pointed out that unlike some infectious diseases, AIDS is spread by specific, controllable behavior. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. ``The policy is ill-conceived and irrational,'' she said. ``Those who are aware they have the disease and are under treatment are the least likely to be any threat.'' Only Congress can rescind the law. In an effort to deal with the criticism, meetings have been held over the last few weeks by the agencies involved in administering it, including the Justice Department, State Department and Department of Health and Human Services. American health officials fear there is not enough time before the meeting in San Francisco for Congress to make sufficient changes in the law to satisfy critics.

DOC.HEAD: As Mutilation Trial Nears, Legislature Speeds Sex-Offender Crackdown Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 2nd graf. Lloyde cq in 16th graf.
DOC.TEXT: An ex-convict charged with sexually mutilating a small boy is scheduled to go on trial Monday as major legislation sparked by public outrage at the crime moves toward passage at the state legislature. Prosecutors say they will seek a life sentence for Earl Kenneth Shriner, 39, if he is convicted on charges he raped and tried to kill the child by severing his penis and choking him during an attack May 20. The child, then 7, was wandering naked and dazed when he was found by his mother and grandmother near his home in woods where the attack occurred. Shriner has pleaded innocent to two counts of rape and one count each of first-degree assault and first-degree attempted murder. The boy is scheduled to testify. ``He doesn't say much, but I can tell by his actions that he would rather run away and hide, but he's also ready to turn and face the problem because he realizes running and hiding isn't the way to end it for him,'' said his mother, Helen Harlow. The child is back in school, and ``doing all the things normal little boys do,'' his mother said. He faces the second of two operations to repair the damage inflicted by his assailant's knife, and ``will be restored to normal functions in every way,'' Ms. Harlow said. The child's medical, psychiatric, and other costs are being paid from a trust fund of $600,000 formed from donations that poured in from all over the country, said Ms. Harlow. She has no access to the fund herself and lives off earnings from a part-time job. The case enraged the public, and led Gov. Booth Gardner to form a special panel that drafted legislation to snare more ``sex predators.'' The measure, heading for unusually quick and almost certain passage in this election year, toughens sex-offender sentences ans creates a procedure to indefinitely commit highly violent offenders through a civil procedure after they have served their criminal sentences. It also requires sex offenders to register with county sheriffs for from 10 to 15 years, and permits authorities to warn communities when an offender is in their midst. The bill was introduced after the legislature convened Jan. 8 and is due for a vote on the Senate floor Monday. Three legislators also are pushing measures authorizing surgical castration of incorrigible sex offenders. Gardner's $17 million package, elements of which have been blasted by the American Civil Liberties Union as ``totalitarian concepts,'' was a direct result of the Shriner case, said state Rep. Marlin Appelwick, who heads the House Judiciary Committee. Other crimes also spurred support for the measure: the 1988 slaying of a Seattle woman by a known sex offender later sentenced to life; the killings of three boys in Vancouver, Wash., last summer, allegedly by a known child molester still facing trial; and the killing of a female jogger last fall in Whatcom County. Police have announced no suspects in the jogger's death. ``My only regret is it took this tragedy with this little boy to get us all to take such a serious look at the damage sex offenders are doing, and when even worse atrocities are happening to women every day,'' Appelwick said. ``It's too bad it took a male victim to get everybody's attention.'' Shriner is being held in lieu of $1 million bail. One of his attorneys, public defender Lloyde Alton, has complained that the tidal wave of publicity threatens his client's right to an impartial jury. The defense won the right to pick the jury in another county and bring the panel to Tacoma, where it will be sequestered. Shriner completed a 10-year prison term for kidnap and assault of two teen-age girls shortly before the attack on the boy. Officials testified at recent legislative hearings that they knew Shriner was likely to commit sex crimes upon release, but under Washington law, had no way to confine him after he served his sentence. Prison officials told legislators they found drawings and diaries in Shriner's prison cell ``with detailed plans'' to sexually assault children. Superior Court Judge Thomas Sauriol ruled against use of the material by the prosecution, which will rely on the boy's testimony and on hair and blood samples, among other things, prosecutors said.

DOC.HEAD: More Partisan Budget Year Likely as Bush Readies Spending Plan
DOC.TEXT: Congress is bracing for partisan budget fights over defense spending, the Social Security system and tax breaks as President Bush prepares to unveil his proposed 1991 fiscal plan at month's end. Bush's budget, which sources say will call for $1.24 trillion in spending, is already being panned by Democrats who control Congress for its expected embrace of assorted dogeared Republican proposals to save money. These include eliminations or reductions of domestic programs like mass transit aid and energy assistance to the poor. ``This will be a dinosaur budget, a warm-over of what we've seen before,'' Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said recently. ``It will be the whole laundry list that Congress hasn't accepted for nine years.'' For their part, Republicans are already showing that they will not be bashful about pushing their own budgetary agenda this year. In a speech last week, Bush referred to ``demagogues'' who are opposing his resurrected proposal to cut the tax rate on capital gains, which he claims will raise money for government coffers. The higher pitched political rhetoric is being fanned by the fact that this is an election year. With the entire House and one-third of the Senate up for re-election in November, members of the two parties plan to use the budget to show voters what they stand for _ and how they differ from their opponents. ``Both parties will be jockeying for position,'' foresees House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``Democrats will be pushing for increased initiatives on human needs, and Republicans will be trying to protect their `No new taxes' pledge. Frankly both positions together aren't going to help'' speed the budget process. The budget year that Bush launches when he submits his spending blueprint to Congress on Jan. 29 is expected to be have three major battlefields. Each contest will shape a crucial part of the savings mix the president needs to heed the Gramm-Rudman law's requirement for a projected deficit next year of no more than $64 billion. Bowing to deficit pressures and to diminishing tensions with the Eastern bloc, Bush plans to call for $303 billion in defense spending, which would be 2 percent less than necessary to keep this year's $297 billion level abreast of inflation. Democrats, with liberals such as Reps. George Miller, D-Calif., and Barney Frank, D-Mass., leading the way, are already saying Bush's cut is not deep enough. Even the more moderate Sasser says he would like to see military spending reduced to about $295 billion. With Democrats holding majorities in the House and Senate, the only questions seem to be how large the so-called ``peace dividend'' will be, and where the savings will go. The majority party is split over the latter, with liberals urging an expansion of ailing domestic programs like education and health, and others hoping to use the savings to lower the deficit. Another fight will be over the huge surpluses the Social Security system is running. There is bipartisan consensus that the surplus does little more than hide the true size of the overall deficit, which was $152 billion last year but would have been $204 billion without the Social Security windfall. The dispute arises over what to do about it. Although opinions on the issue cross party lines, Republicans tend to couple removal of the Social Security surpluses from deficit calculations with an extension of the Gramm-Rudman law. That legislation, which mandates a balanced budget in 1993 and then expires, tends to keep domestic spending down. Most Democrats oppose a Gramm-Rudman extension. A wild card is a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., who wants to lower the 7.65 percent payroll tax employers and workers pay to support Social Security. The plan puts Bush in the uncomfortable position of opposing a tax cut, but opponents say the reduction would jeopardize the savings needed to pay Baby Boomers' retirement benefits. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., in his first public statement on the plan, said Sunday he would vote against the plan if he had to vote on it now. He called for the proposal to be studied ``very carefully.'' Also likely to cause a clash is Bush's capital gains reduction plan. Democrats, who say the proposal is actually a money-loser, narrowly defeated it in 1989 after a bitter political clash, but concede that the measure will likely be enacted this year. A fight will evolve as Democrats struggle to win something in return, perhaps an improved individual retirement account to benefit the middle- and lower-class. Other elements of the year's budget clash should sound familiar. Chief among them will be questions over the administration's economic projections. The better the economic forecast, the more revenues the government can expect to collect and the lower the anticipated deficit. Administration sources say they will project next year's economic growth to be about 2.6 percent, well above the amount many private economists expect. Since the Gramm-Rudman law requires use of the administration forecast, Democrats are helpless to do more than complain. Using these optimistic projections, the White House is expected to say that it needs $30 billion to $35 billion in savings to reach the Gramm-Rudman deficit target of $64 billion. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office is expected to say that the needed savings will be more than twice as high. Bush is expected to propose minor initiatives in certain education, environment, anti-drug, child care and science programs. Democrats are ready to claim that his proposals fall short of what is needed.

DOC.HEAD: Witch Hunts Thwart U.S. Efforts in Panama
LaserPhoto PAN-3 of Jan. 20
DOC.TEXT: Panamanians have gone on a spree of witch hunts in the political shake-up following the U.S. invasion, sometimes using American troops to settle personal vendettas, U.S. Army and Panamanian sources say. The persistent accusations, dismissals of public employees and charges made in the news media are hindering the organization of President Guillermo Endara's new government, frustrating American officials and delaying the removal of U.S. forces, according to the sources. ``Everyone has turned into a squealer,'' said Army Col. Charles Morris, director of a 200-member special group called in to help the new government organize itself. ``They have gone wild,'' said another U.S. Army source on condition of anonymity. ``They are using the U.S. Army for their own personal revenge. We get calls from someone saying there are weapons in some house, and we have to check it.'' Shortly after the Dec. 20 invasion toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the U.S. Army began acting as a police force for the new government. American forces have arrested not only former members of Noriega's high command, but leftists and leaders of old political parties, including the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party that backed the old government. As of Friday, the U.S. Army still held 100 military and civilian prisoners at Fort Clayton at ``the request of the Panamanian government,'' which was sorting out possible charges against some of them. Newspapers have become a daily register of purported wrongdoings by government officials, business leaders and politicians who once had some tie to Noriega. U.S. soldiers, often following tips from neighbors or ideological foes, arrested many members of leftist political parties and held them for two or three days. In some cases, their main sin was militancy in the Communist Party. ``The soldiers would come in and arrest someone, or they would go into an office and take what they wanted,'' said Mario Rognoni, who spent three days in custody because he served in government under Noriega. ``Then they would encourage people to loot the place so they could blame the sacking on them.'' ``The Army took our computer, our records, and then left it open so people could take everything else,'' alleged Rognoni, a Democratic Revolutionary Party leader. The retaliation has even extended to the girlfriends and mistresses of pro-Noriega officials, who have had sofas, cars and even dishes seized on the assumption they were bought with stolen money. Leaders of the new political opposition claim more than 8,000 public employees have been fired after they were accused of having been loyal to the past regime. ``But many of the public employees were forced by the (Noriega) government to participate in pro-government demonstrations or join the paramilitary groups. It was either that or lose their jobs,'' said a former member of a paramilitary organization. ``What were you supposed to do when you have a family to feed?'' The Endara government has seized at least 10 radio stations and two television stations owned by people suspected of association with Noriega. More than 100 official accusations or private lawsuits filed against former government officials have piled up at the attorney general's office. All must be investigated, said Attorney General Rogelio Cruz. Meanwhile, the two competing newspapers, La Estrella and El Siglo, have been trying to outdo each other showing how close to Noriega the other's director was. ``There is hatred; there is desire for revenge. The country has gone mad,'' said Rognoni. ``The worst part,'' said a politician who spoke on condition of anonymity, ``is that the new `ins' who now own this country did not fight for it. ``The gringos gave it to them on a silver platter. They did not shed a single drop of blood for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversy over Northern Ireland Inquiry Flares Again
DOC.TEXT: John Stalker, the cop whose thwarted investigation came to symbolize doubts about justice in Northern Ireland, is back to haunt the British government. Stalker, who was removed in 1986 before completing an inquiry into killings by police in Northern Ireland, says he has documentary proof his ouster was engineered by ``senior civil servants, possibly at the Cabinet level'' in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government. If Stalker is to be believed _ and the government strongly denies it _ his removal was intended to obstruct an investigation of alleged murder and perjury by officers of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Northern Ireland's police force. Trevor Forbes, recently retired as chief of the RUC's anti-terrorist Special Branch, was quoted by The Sunday Times as saying ``there was no conspiracy and no cover-up within the RUC.'' If there had been, he argued, Stalker's deputy also would have been removed, but he was not. Stalker's new claim of proof came last week after fraud charges against his friend, Kevin Taylor, were dismissed in Manchester Crown Court. It was Stalker's alleged association with ``known criminals'' that led to his suspension from the investigation. His association with Taylor was at the core of the inquiry. ``I have always said that the charges against Mr. Taylor were a contrivance, a means of getting at me through him,'' Stalker said. Taylor's attorneys said detectives lied to obtain a warrant to examine Taylor's bank records. Documents relating to the warrant are now missing, prosecutors acknowledge. Taylor intends to sue for malicious prosecution, his attorneys said. Britain's Director of Public Prosecutions, Allen Green, asked Greater Manchester Police to investigate their handling of the case that was so damaging to Stalker, who was then Manchester's second-highest officer. ``No one involved in the Greater Manchester Police should be involved in the inquiry except as witnesses,'' protested Cecil Franks, a lawmaker from Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party and longtime supporter of Stalker. Home Secretary David Waddington, the Cabinet official responsible for law enforcement, resisted calls for a judicial inquiry. ``People are too prone these days to come up with conspiracy theories without looking at what, in fact, happened,'' Waddington said. ``If Mr. Stalker has a document which he feels is relevant, I am sure he will produce it.'' Stalker said he would do that but only to ``someone with direct access to and authority from the Cabinet.'' The Stalker story goes back to Oct. 27, 1982, when Irish Republican Army guerrillas killed three RUC officers in an ambush with a land mine. On Nov. 11, 1982, three suspects identified by an informer were shot to death by Special Branch officers. On Nov. 24, the same unit killed one man and wounded another near a hay barn, where police believed the mine that killed their colleagues had been stored. On Dec. 12, two more suspects were killed by the same Special Branch unit. The IRA admitted that the first three men killed were its ``volunteers,'' and the Irish National Liberation Army, an IRA splinter, claimed the last two. No terrorist connection, however, was made to Michael Tighe, 17, who was killed at the hay shed. Facing a storm of accusations that the RUC had a ``shoot-to-kill'' policy, Chief Constable Sir John Hermon appointed Stalker in March 1984 to conduct an independent investigation. Stalker has said he admired the courage of many RUC officers and sympathized with their difficulties in battling terrorism, but he was appalled by the slapdash quality of the RUC's own investigations of the killings. His most piquant discovery was that police and army intelligence had been bugging the hay shed when Tighe was killed. Stalker pressed Hermon for access to the tape and for more information about the use of informers. ``I was within a couple of days of obtaining the vital tape'' and of being allowed to question Hermon, when he was told that he was himself under investigation for alleged involvement with criminals, Stalker wrote in his book on the affair. Stalker was formally suspended in June 1986. He was reinstated as deputy chief constable within 10 weeks but the investigation was completed by another officer who recommended prosecution of some RUC officers. Attorney General Sir Patrick Mayhew ultimately decided against prosecution, citing national security. Last year, 18 RUC officers were disciplined for minor offenses related to the case. Hermon has retired.

DOC.HEAD: 21 Reported Killed in Kashmir Violence
DOC.TEXT: Troops battled mobs of Moslem separatists in the Kashmir city of Srinagar over the weekend, and at least 21 people were killed and 100 wounded before the fighting subsided Sunday night, police said. Fifteen demonstrators were shot and killed Sunday, while six were fatally wounded late Saturday night, according to Mohammad Nomani, inspector general of Srinagar police. Militants defied a curfew and continued trading intermittent shots with government forces on Sunday, officials said. Witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the death toll was at least 30, but that figure could not be confirmed. Nomani, speaking by telephone from Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, said the fighting tapered off late Sunday afternoon as heavy rains lashed the city. But gunfire echoed through the deserted streets until evening, one resident said, requesting anonymity. ``They (the troops) are shooting at anything moving,'' he said. ``It is a disastrous situation out there,'' said Ramesh Kaul, a hotel receptionist in Srinagar. At least 47 people have been killed in Jammu-Kashmir state since the beginning of the year in violence triggered by Moslem militants demanding independence or union with Islamic Pakistan. The separatists, led by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, have often attacked government offices and police officials. ``The situation is tense and dangerous,'' the state's chief secretary, Moosa Raza, said in Jammu, the state's winter capital 95 miles south of Srinagar. Nomani said the police dispatched 25 cars with loudspeakers into the city, to appeal to people to obey the curfew. The cars were escorted by heavily armed troops from the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force, he said. A 24-hour curfew was imposed Saturday in a bid to quell escalating violence and mass anti-India demonstrations in Srinagar and nearby towns. But late Saturday, crowds defied curfew and surged into downtown Srinagar chanting ``Indian dogs go back!'' and ``Long live Pakistan!'' local reporters said. They said the paramilitary troops opened fire, killing two people instantly and injuring 14. Four of them died later. As news of the shootings spread, thousands of Moslem men poured out of their homes, the reporters said. They said protesters recited verses from the Koran, the Moslem holy book. Some took up a chant urging ``mujahedeen,'' or Islamic holy warriors, to prepare for the final sacrifice in a showdown with India's Hindu-dominated government. Jammu-Kashmir's former state chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, issued a statement accusing authorities of letting loose a ``reign of terror and repression.'' Abdullah's Moslem-dominated National Conference Party is closely aligned with the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi, the arch political foe of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Abdullah's government resigned Friday to protest the appointment of Singh's nominee as the state's new governor and imposition of governor's rule which amounts to tighter federal control over the state. The curfew order was one of the first acts of the new governor, Jagmohan, a tough administrator who had cracked down on Kashmiri militants during an earlier stint as the state's governor. Jagmohan, a Hindu who uses one name, took office Friday. Parts of Kashmir region are claimed by both India and Pakistan. The dispute started when the state was partitioned between the two countries when they gained independence from Britain in 1947. Srinagar's 800,000 people are moslty Moslem, as is a majority of population in the Kashmir region. The Jammu region is predominantly Hindu. India has often accused Pakistan of aiding the Kashmiri militants, a charge Pakistan has denied. Jammu-Kashmir is the only state with a Moslem majority in predominantly Hindu India. Moslems make up 64 percent of the state population of 5 million. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus comprise 82 percent.
