Tens of thousands of anti-Communist protesters carrying suitcases marched across the border from Duderstadt to Goettingen, West Germany, in a symbolic exodus but returned later in the day. West Germany's ARD television said about 60,000 people were involved but police in Goettingen put the number at about 25,000. Wolfgang Berghofer, a reformer who was the Communist Party's deputy chairman, resigned along with 39 other prominent members in his home city of Dresden, the official news agency ADN said. ``With deep regret for our country, we the undersigned declare our resignation from the Communist Party, and with this step we include the urgent demand that the Communist Party be broken up,'' Berghofer said in a statement read to reporters in Dresden. Three breakaway Communist factions are trying to establish themselves as separate political forces, and government television said Berghofer's move put the party's future in ``extreme danger.'' Berghofer also said he and the others ``support the growing together of the two German states within the framework of European unity.'' It was unclear whether he was specifically endorsing German reunification. Berghofer, Dresden's 46-year-old mayor, is credited with helping to head off a potential massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in October. He was the first official to call for a free-market economy. Berghofer has been widely reported to be joining the opposition Social Democratic party, although Sunday's announcement made no mention of such a step. His desertion is expected to spark a further exodus from the party, whose membership has plunged from nearly 2.3 million in 1987 to 1.2 million currently. In a two-day meeting that ended Sunday, the Communists expelled Krenz and 13 members of the ousted ruling Politburo. It rejected demands to disband but promised ``radical reform and consolidation'' and rehabilitated 47 East Germans punished for speaking out against former hard-line Communist leaders. Krenz immediately appealed his expulsion, becoming the first former top leader to fight back publicly. A dozen former leaders were kicked out in December and nine are in prison awaiting corruption trials. The official announcement did not specify a reason for Sunday's purge. However, the Communists are moving to rid themselves of the last of the top officials associated with Erich Honecker, the hard-liner replaced by Krenz on Oct. 18 after 18 years in power. Honecker was kicked out of the party in December and now faces an indictment for high treason. Other members of his government have been accused of corruption. Krenz, seen as a Honecker protege, inherited the helm of a country spinning out of control. Thousands were fleeing daily to the West while others demonstrated for reform. Trying to stem the exodus and remain in power, Krenz opened the Berlin Wall and other barriers to the West on Nov. 9 and promised other reform, but he was ousted himself after just six weeks in office. Prosecutors opened a criminal probe against Communist Finance Minister Uta Nickel, who becomes the first member of Premier Hans Modrow's coalition government to be accused of wrongdoing. Nickel is accused of having been involved in ``illegal payments'' in her former post as member of the state finance and price council in Leipzig, ADN said. It did not elaborate. After an all-day leadership session Saturday, the Communists offered the opposition ``co-responsibility'' in the caretaker government, but it was not immediately clear whether that included ministerial posts in Modrow's Cabinet. A mass-circulation West German newspaper, Bild, reported that East German secret police and army troops apparently were preparing a coup in case of another general strike by government opponents. Bild cited unidentified opposition sources in East Germany. Aside from the report, there were no other indications a coup was being prepared. The newspaper said opposition groups will ask for control of the interior and justice ministries and that if Modrow's government refuses, they will call for a general strike for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Boston Residents See Racial Tension As Residual Effect In Stuart Case
DOC.TEXT: Two of three city residents say the twisted case of victim-turned-villain Charles Stuart created new tension between Boston's black and white communties, according to a poll published Sunday. Sixty-seven percent of the 400 people polled said the nationally publicized case had damaged race relations in the city, while 27 percent said it had not. The remainder expressed no opinion or declined to comment. Public sentiment, however, was not so divided over other issues involving the slaying of Carol Stuart, whose husband killed himself after being implicated in the shooting he originally blamed on a black mugger. The poll published in Sunday's editions of the Boston Globe and broadcast by WBZ-TV showed marked differences among the city's blacks and whites as to how police and Mayor Raymond L. Flynn handled the Oct. 23 killing, whether they consider Boston safe and whether they advocate a police stop-and-search policy. Nine of 10 black residents surveyed said they believe the city Police Department overreacted in its investigation of the Stuart case, while white residents responded by a 5-4 ratio that the police response was warranted. Flynn, whom many black leaders have blamed for encouraging a blanket search of the Mission Hill neighborhood following the murder, still retained support with a 68-percent-to-20 percent favorable rating that reflected nearly even support from both blacks and whites. Among blacks, 32 percent said they would be less likely to vote for Flynn for governor because of the Stuart case while 47 percent said it would have no impact. Among whites, 19 percent said the case would have a negative effect while 68 percent said it would have no impact. Flynn is considered a potential candidate for governor this fall. Experts said the survey, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percent, clearly indicated that the city's black and white communities had dissimilar views of the Stuart case. ``In question after question there is a clear and significant difference of opinion between blacks and whites about the case,'' said pollster Gerry Chervinsky of KRC Communications Research, which handled the poll. ``By and large, whites believe there was an action that was perpetrated by Stuart that duped everybody, and that Flynn, the district attorney and the Police Department did what they should have done. The black community doesn't seem to buy into that.'' Among other findings in the poll: _ Seventy-four percent of blacks polled said they believed police improperly persuaded witnesses to implicate William Bennett, a black man later cleared in Mrs. Stuart's slaying. That compared with 42 percent of the whites. _ Overall, 57 percent of the respondents said they believe black suspects in crimes are treated more harshly than white suspects. Blacks, by a 7-to-1 ratio, said they believe black suspects are treated more harshly. Eighty-five percent of blacks questioned, compared with 51 percent of whites, do not believe police administer justice equally in all Boston neighborhoods. _ Fifty-three percent of blacks questioned, compared with 25 percent of whites, said they do not feel personally safe living in Boston. _ Fifty-five percent of blacks and 49 percent of whites said the news media had done a below-average job of reporting the story. Although Flynn retained a high favorability rating, he and his colleagues, District Attorney Newman Flanagan and Police Commissioner Mickey Roache, scored badly in their handling of the Stuart case with the trio's performance rated below-average by about 54 percent of blacks and 32 percent of whites.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations Across Country on Eve of Roe v. Wade Anniversary
LaserPhoto PN1
DOC.TEXT: Activists on both sides of the abortion issue rallied across the country Sunday, waging a renewed battle over abortion rights at the state level the day before the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling. In one indication of new fervor over the issue, an estimated 25,000 to 30,000 people joined dueling rallies in Phoenix, where a demonstration in support of abortion rights drew just 250 a year ago. Elsewhere, demonstrators sang and chanted for abortion rights in Albany, N.Y, lined up along a busy commercial street in Southern California and held ``baby showers'' for poor women who choose to have children in Provo, Utah. Demonstrations also were held in Boston, Raleigh, N.C., and Spokane, Wash. Speakers called for renewed action by state legislatures following a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision modifying Roe vs. Wade, which legalized abortion in this country. The summer decision, Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services, allowed states to regulate abortion in some cases. ``It may take another year, it may take another five years, it may take 10 years, but we will bring constitutional protections to the unborn in the womb,'' Jim Skelly, chairman of the Arizona House Judiciary Committee, told the Phoenix rally. Other rallies were held Saturday. For anti-abortion forces, the weekend of activity was to culminate Monday with a march on the U.S. Capitol and other demonstrations around the country. President Bush was scheduled to address the Washington ``March for Life.'' Demonstrators Sunday were peaceful, including in Phoenix, where the anti-abortion group marched past the abortion-rights contingent and released red balloons. Shouts were exchanged, but police and rally marshals from both groups kept the peace. In Southern California, 5,000 people linked arms to line the sides of Beach Boulevard along parts of a five-mile stretch through the cities of Anaheim and Westminster to dramatize their opposition to abortion. A similer ``life chain'' was formed by 2,000 people at the California Capitol in Sacramento, who cheered fellow demonstrators in a motorcade led by a hearse plastered with anti-abortion slogans. About 1,000 abortion-rights supporters trying to stage a counterdemonstration were forced to rally outside the Capitol Mall because they lacked a permit. In Provo, Utah, right-to-life group sponsored several ``baby showers'' to gather donated maternity clothes and baby gifts for needy women who spurned abortion. Several thousand anti-abortion demonstrators gathered for a day of speeches and song at the state Capitol in Oklahoma City. One speaker, law professor Teresa Stanton Collett, bemoaned the state of public debate on the issue. ``The abortion dialogue is reducing women on that side of the street to waving hangers dipped in red paint while women on the other side are waving signs with gross pictures on them,'' Ms. Collett said, pointing to pro-choice supporters. ``The debate ought to be how we deal with women, children and families. Abortion is the quick fix we can't afford.'' In Albany, N.Y., abortion-rights activists, some of whom arrived on cross-country skis in a heavy snowstorm, chanted, sang and shouted a pledge to lobby their view in the statehouse. As they met in the legislative office building, about 60 people demonstrated against abortion. ``I pledge not to vote for or support with my money or my time any candidate for any office who does not fully support and work for women's equality and the right to safe, legal and accessible abortion,'' the crowd shouted out in response to Marilyn Fitterman, president of the New York State chapter of the National Organization for Women.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Communist Party to Cut Privileges For Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's ruling Communist Party ordered a reduction in privileges for party officials and said some ``special'' health clinics and a hotel will be made available to workers, the official Tass news agency said Sunday. The report comes a day after a foreign source in the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator, said the Communist government banned demonstrations in the wake of protests by a fledgling pro-reform movement. Tass said in a report from Ulan Bator that the Communist Party's ruling Politburo approved the decree on cuts to party officials in preparation of a 20th party congress scheduled for November. Tass said the Politburo decided to close a special food store and reduce the number of official cars. The Politburo also ``considered several issues pertaining to benefits for leading workers,'' Tass said. ``It was decided to transfer special clinics to the Ministry of Health of Mongolia and to transfer to the Central Council of Mongolian Trade Unions a government hotel complex,'' the news agency said. Hard-line Communist governments ousted in Eastern Europe last year were criticized for providing lavish perks to party officials. The foreign source, contacted by telephone in Ulan Bator, said Saturday that the city council placed a temporary ban on demonstrations in squares, main streets, factories and key enterprises. The measure was announced on television and reported in newspapers Friday, the source said. The ban came after three street rallies staged during the past month by the newly formed Mongolian Democratic Union, a group of intellectuals and artists advocating a faster pace of economic and political reform. The ban was accompanied by a commentary in the Communist Party paper Unen on Friday that for the first time criticized the Mongolian Democratic Union and some of its leading members. The article said the group was pushing too far in its campaign for reform and was failing to listen to the advice of its friends and elders. Mongolia, a nation of 2 million scattered across the vast deserts and grasslands of eastern Asia between China and the Soviet Union, has cautiously followed the lead of its patron state, the Soviet Union, in introducing ``glasnost'' and ``perestroika.'' However, the inefficient government-run economy still fails to meet many basic consumer needs, and unlike in Eastern Europe there has been no challenge to one-party Communist rule. According to a report by Tass, the Mongolian Democratic Union claims a membership of 60,000. It has spoken out against ``commandism,'' the authoritarian methods of party and bureaucratic powers, and demanded that Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal, Mongolia's autocratic ruler for more than three decades before he was purged in 1984, be put on trial. Foreign sources in the capital also said a small statue of Stalin was stolen last week and another prominent statue of the Soviet leader was splashed with paint. Vandals also threw paint on a statue of Horloogiyn Choybalsan, the Stalinist leader responsible for widespread purges during the 1930s. It was not known who was responsible for the vandalism.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Places French, American, British Satellites In Orbit
DOC.TEXT: An Ariane 4 rocket blasted off Sunday night from the European Space Agency's jungle launch pad, carrying a French earth observation satellite and several smaller satellites for U.S. and British clients. The 35th Ariane rocket lifted off the launch pad on the northern coast of South America at 10:35 p.m. The launch had been scheduled Saturday night, but heavy cloud cover forced a 24-hour postponement. Less than half an hour after the launch, Arianespace officials announced that all the satellites were placed successfully in orbit. It was the first time the new generation Ariane 4 rocket was flown without extra strap-on boosters since the rocket went into service last year. Ariane shots have become routine, and the reliability of the program has made Arianespace the world's leading provider of commercial launch services, holding more than 50 percent of the lucrative international market. Arianespace has a backlog of at least 32 payloads. Sunday's launch carried into orbit French-designed Spot 2 earth observation satellite, which will replace the Spot 1. Among the six microsatellites were a 26-pound Microsat for the U.S.-based International Association of Amateur Radio Operators, AMSAT, and an 88-pound Uosat telecommunications satellite for the University of Surrey in Guildford, England. Arianespace, a consortium of European companies, took over the commercialization of the Ariane program from the European Space Agency in 1980. It is responsible for building, operating and marketing launch services.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Tanker Grounding Spills 57,000 Gallons of Gasoline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE description of spill, move up that spill not expected to cause major environmental damage; picks up 7th graf, `That type ...' SUBS grafs 15-17 to UPDATE with crew tested for drug use, special oil spill team arrived.
DOC.TEXT: A tanker ran aground in a narrow channel in Alaska's scenic Inside Passage, spilling an estimated 57,600 gallons of gasoline, the Coast Guard said. The spill was not expected to cause widespread environmental damage because gasoline evaporates quickly, Coast Guard and state environmental officials said. The 400-foot motor vessel Frank H. Brown slammed into Burnt Island reef about 18 miles south of Petersburg in southeastern Alaska around 8 p.m. Saturday, said Lt. Rick Janelle in Juneau. One tank was ruptured but the leak was stopped by about 10 p.m., Janelle said. The Canadian-owned ship refloated itself about 8:30 a.m. Sunday, around high tide, said Ed Moreth, another Coast Guard spokesman. It was taken to nearby Skow Bay, where divers found a two-foot hole in the hull. The tanker's crew measured the amount of gasoline left in the ruptured tank and found that 57,600 gallons had spilled, Moreth said. The spill is tiny in comparison to the March 24 Exxon Valdez disaster which dumped 11 million gallons of heavy, long-lasting crude oil into Alaska waters. Exxon Corp. says it has spent more than $1 billion cleaning up the nation's largest oil spill. By late Sunday the Coast Guard reported three light sheens of gasoline in the channel, the largest a mile long. ``None of the fuel is deemed recoverable,'' a news release said. ``That type of fuel does dissipate faster than most oil products,'' Moreth said. ``We expect a lot of it has evaporated or has broken up. That's what we're looking for.'' Coast Guard spokesman Greg Robinson said there were no immediate plans to try to remove the gasoline. A private pilot reported seeing gasoline trailing a half-mile from the vessel, but Coast Guard pilots described it as a thin ``sheen'' of unrecoverable gasoline on the water's surface. The state's Crystal Lake Hatchery nearby wasn't threatened by the spill, fish culturist Bill Davidson said at the salmon hatchery. The spill isn't expected to pose a health risk to people in the area, said Barbara Holian, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Conservation. Conservation officials were working with fish and game experts to identify sensitive areas and protect them with booms, she said. The spill occurred in the Wrangell Narrows, a 24-mile long channel amid the mountainous, thickly forested islands of the Inside Passage, which runs along the Alaskan and Canadian coasts between Seattle and Juneau. Moreth said there were no signs of wildlife damage. The captain told the Coast Guard the accident was caused by ``a judgment error'' but didn't elaborate, said Moreth, who didn't know the captain's name. The Coast Guard took blood and urine samples from the crew to test for drug and alcohol use. Bad weather prevented the Coast Guard from sending out a helicopter to inspect the site from the air, Moreth said. Three Coast Guard cutters were on scene, however, and their crews were trying to determine the extent of the spill, Moreth said. The Coast Guard's California-based Pacific Strike Team of spill experts arrived in Petersburg to assist the cleanup, he said. The vessel has been surrounded by booms to contain any further leakage. ``Plans are to take the vessel to Scow Bay which is just south of Petersburg,'' Moreth said. ``We'll assess damage there.'' The owner has hired divers to inspect the outside of the vessel, and the Coast Guard will board the vessel to inspect the inside to see if any other cargo tanks have been damaged, he said. The owner has hired a tug and barge to remove what fuel remains aboard the tanker, Moreth said. The tanker, owned by White Pass Transportation of Vancouver, British Columbia, carries 1.8 million gallons of mixed fuels, including diesel oil, stove oil and gasoline. The Wrangell Narrows is a windy channel of water about 18 miles long that connects Petersburg with larger bodies of water in the Inside Passage.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Toward Elections Starts with Diet Resumption
DOC.TEXT: The countdown toward a crucial parliamentary election started Monday as a new legislative session opened, and politicians began consultations expected to lead to nationwide voting on Feb. 18. The election will be critical in showing whether the long-governing Liberal Democrats can retain voter loyalty in spite of a series of scandals and public dislike of a new sales tax that forced two prime ministers out of office last year. Emperor Akihito officially opened a joint session of the upper House of Councillors and the more powerful House of Representatives, but on Wednesday Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is expected to dissolve the lower house. Kaifu, who has the final say on dissolving the lower house and setting the election date, hasn't spoken officially yet, but other leaders in the governing Liberal Democratic Party have been saying for weeks that Feb. 18 will be election day. The Liberal Democrats hold 297 seats in the 512-seat lower house, while the Socialist Party, the largest opposition group, holds only 85, a figure they hope to almost double. If the conservative Liberal Democrats fall short of a bare majority of 257 seats, Japanese politics could be thrown into a confusing period of coalition-building in which different parties attempt to group together with enough seats to take a majority in the lower house. The Diet, Japan's Parliament, had been in recess since the end of 1989. While the upper house, where the opposition had held a majority since last summer when the Liberal Democrats lost their majority for the first time in 34 years, opened Monday, the House of Representatives is not scheduled to resume a plenary session until Wednesday. It is expected that Kaifu will dissolve the lower house as soon as it opens and declare Feb. 18 the date to elect new members of that house. The upper house is elected on a separate schedule. The election will come about five months early, as the last election for a four-year term was held July 6, 1986. Opening the new session, the emperor declared, ``I hope earnestly the Diet, the highest organ of state power, will completely fulfill its mission and meet the people's trust.'' Akihito said Japan's Parliament strives to improve the people's lives and to spread peace and prosperity in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Offers Help To Visiting Lebanese President
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad on Sunday awarded Lebanese President Elias Hrawi with Syria's highest civilian honor, the Medal of Merit, after talks on how to end a rebellion in Lebanon by Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. It was Hrawi's first visit outside Lebanon since he was elected president in November. Government spokesman Jibrane Kourieh quoted Assad as pledging that Syria ``will spare no effort to provide any assistance'' the Lebanese government requests to implement an Arab League-sponsored peace plan to end Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war. He did not elaborate, but it was a clear reference to Syria providing troops and tanks to help Hrawi assert his government's authority over the Christian enclave controlled by Aoun. The general refuses to recognize Hrawi or his government and has branded them ``Syrian puppets.'' Syria has an estimated 40,000 troops in Lebanon under an Arab League mandate. Government-run Damascus Radio said Assad also awarded medals to Lebanon's prime minister, Salim Hoss, and Parliament Speaker Hussein Husseini during the ceremony at the presidential palace. It did not say why the awards were made. But the three Lebanese leaders head a Syrian-backed government that has endorsed the Arab League peace plan that shifts political power to the Moslem majority. The radio said Hrawi hailed Syria's ``brotherly'' position on Lebanon and the cooperation between the two countries and thanked Syria for ``the help it has offered to Lebanon.'' Hrawi aide May Kahaleh said Hrawi and Assad discussed how to tighten control of Lebanon's borders to prevent non-Lebanese entering the country. She did not elaborate, but she was apparently referring to Yasser Arafat's Palestinian guerrillas, who have reestablished bases in south Lebanon, and are sympathetic to Aoun's cause. Hrawi and Assad also want to stop shipments of arms and ammunition reaching Aoun, who is bottled up in the Christian enclave north of Beirut. Aoun rejects the peace accord, which gives Moslems a greater share of power with the traditionally dominant Christians, because it does not provide for a complete Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. Hrawi was elected in November shortly after his predecessor, Rene Mouawad, was assassinated in Beirut only 17 days after he was elected.

DOC.HEAD: Federated's Corporate Star Dimmed by Reorganization Filing
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Charles Luken puts in perspective the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of Federated Department Stores Inc., a corporate cornerstone here for 45 years, by remembering how the city endured the turmoil surrounding another local institution last year. ``It kind of reminds me of the Pete Rose (gambling investigation). People used to ask me whether it hurt the city,'' Luken said. ``I used to say the city's bigger than that, and I say the same in this case.'' Rose was manager of the Cincinnati Reds until he was banned from baseball for allegedly betting on the game. Now attention is on Federated and Allied Stores Corp., two Cincinnati-based department store chains that Toronto-based Campeau Corp. placed under bankruptcy protection last week. Federated was founded in 1929 in Columbus by the families that owned Abraham and Strauss in Brooklyn, Filene's in Boston and Lazarus in Columbus. Bloomingdale's in New York joined the company three months later. Federated moved headquarters to Cincinnati in 1945. The company has long supported community projects, giving millions of dollars to charities and civic programs. The Federated Department Stores Foundation gave $8.5 million last year to such causes as AIDS research and minority college scholarships, according to foundation Director Pat Ikeda. Ms. Ikeda said she didn't know whether the bankruptcy court filing would affect the foundation, which is supported by an independent trust fund. ``It's possible that everything will remain the same,'' she said. Nevertheless, the mayor said cutbacks at Federated and the time that financial problems have demanded from executives have drastically reduced the company's traditional prominence in civic activities. ``They were involved in everything, from the low-income housing projects to being a primary sponsor of our bicentennial celebration'' in 1988, Luken said. ``I just don't call them anymore. It's not life or death, but it's a tremendous resource that's been lost to us.'' Another sign of the change is a part of Cincinnati's skyline. Federated put its 21-story headquarters building up for sale last week to raise money to service its $5.3 billion debt. Campeau Corp. went deeply into debt to buy Federated in April 1988 for $6.6 billion, increasing its original offer by $2.4 billion to win a bidding war with R.H. Macy & Co. of New York. Campeau had bought Allied Stores Corp. in December 1986 for $3.6 billion. Many residents blame Chairman Robert Campeau for Federated's problems. ``I think Campeau and company took what was a viable company and really screwed it up,'' said Ocie Hammond, a manager at another Cincinnati corporate heavyweight, Procter & Gamble Co. Said Luken: ``I look at this as a glitch resulting from greed run amok of one individual who didn't care very much for the human suffering he occasioned on the people who've given their lives to the company.'' The problem goes well beyond Campeau himself, though, said John Williams, president of the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce. ``I think that's simplistic. He's the senior man, but I guess I blame the whole phenomenon of hostile takeovers and the whole slew of people who profit from them at the expense of the community,'' Williams said. Hammond said he was disappointed that Campeau found so many willing backers. ``Their business plan was overly optimistic, and to my dismay, the banks bought it,'' he said. Federated's department stores remain profitable, but Hammond said the parent company's financial problems could affect its ability to attract good employees. ``I do recruiting for P&G at colleges, and the image of a company has a lot to do with whether top students sign up for job interviews,'' he said. Dorothy Speer, a longtime shopper at Lazarus, said she expects the company's department stores to survive the financial crisis, even if they are sold to another retail chain. ``I think they'll come back,'' she said. ``I am concerned that they will close, and I would not like to see that happen,'' Bonnie Patton, an engineer for AT&T, said outside the downtown Lazarus store. ``This is the only store in Cincinnati that has something for everybody. It's the only place I shop.''

DOC.HEAD: Mary Cunningham Agee Develops Alternatives To Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Mary Cunningham Agee has dropped out of the world of business and profits to pursue a goal closer to her heart: helping young women make it through unwanted pregnancies. She believes even abortion-rights advocates can see the value of such efforts. A decade ago, Mrs. Agee made headlines when she was forced to resign as a Bendix Corp. vice president amid rumors of a romance with her boss, William Agee. In 1982, the two wed, although they both deny they were romantically involved during the time she was at Bendix. Since she started the Nurturing Network almost four years ago, she has helped some 800 middle-class single women have babies from unplanned pregnancies. And as the nation marks Monday's anniversary of Roe vs. Wade, the landmark 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, she says, ``People on both sides of the debate can be very much in favor of what I'm doing.'' The non-profit network marshals the resources of thousands of volunteers across the country to help single working women and college students get through the social stigma, family denial, financial difficulty and employer animosity caused by ``crisis pregnancies.'' ``With all this great discussion about freedom of choice, the irony was that the choice that was not available was not the abortion choice, but the birth choice,'' Mrs. Agee said. ``To me, that was a galvanizing piece of information that continues to be missed in this very heated discussion.'' ``The Nurturing Network gave me hope when I despaired early on,'' wrote Kate, a 23-year-old woman helped by the organization last fall when she faced the prospect of having to quit her job because she was pregnant. Some pro-choice advocates question the motives of a group with an agenda so clearly opposed to abortion. Mrs. Agee, 38, is a devout Roman Catholic. ``I would wonder that the purpose might not actually be to help these women carry to term,'' said Jane Johnson, vice president of affiliate development and education for the Washington, D.C.-based Planned Parenthood Federation of America. However, Ms. Johnson said, ``so long as women's rights to make autonomous decisions are not interfered with, I have no problem with somebody helping them carry out their wishes.'' Mrs. Agee's ordeal in the spotlight began when William Agee, who became Bendix chairman and chief executive officer in 1977, hired the then-Ms. Cunningham and rapidly promoted her. Critics speculated that her advance up the Bendix ladder stemmed from more than just talent and a Harvard business degree, although both she and Agee stoutly denied romantic involvement. She resigned as Bendix vice president for strategic planning in 1980, but her and Agee's problems didn't end there. Before she left the company, the two drafted an aggressive takeover strategy that resulted in Bendix's disastrous attempt to buy Martin Marietta Corp. Eventually, Bendix was acquired by what is now Allied-Signal Inc., Agee left the company and he and Mrs. Agee for a time formed a venture capital and consulting firm in Massachusetts. Mrs. Agee launched the Nurturing Network in Massachusetts in 1986 after having a miscarriage, which she says started her thinking about the desperation some women feel when abortion seems like the only alternative. She moved the network to Boise when her husband was hired as chairman and chief executive officer of Morrison Knudson Corp. in 1988. The couple have two children. Researching the issue, she found that most women who have abortions are not underprivileged, confused teen-agers, but women 20 to 24 with at least a high school education. Many are ``goal-oriented'' women working their way through college or pursuing a career, unprepared to put their plans aside but unwilling to end a pregnancy. With most assistance programs geared toward helping teen-agers and the poor, middle-class women in growing numbers have turned to abortion, Mrs. Agee said. To make it easier for such women to avoid abortion if they wish, Mrs. Agee, a full-time staff of three and dozens of volunteers recruit physicians, counselors, families, employers, colleges and financial contributors to the Nurturing Network. It has almost 3,500 members nationwide. Members are asked to provide medical care, a job, a temporary home or a change of schools for network clients, Mrs. Agee said. The services are tailored to individual needs and many are provided at no charge. Mrs. Agee said many of the woman who seek help don't know about the Bendix flap and most of those who do are unfazed by her notoriety. Her organization has tried to stay away from the abortion issue, even as Idaho lawmakers debate whether to enact restrictive legislation in the wake of last year's U.S. Supreme Court decision giving states some limited additional authority. ``The Nurturing Network is not a forum for me to push forward my position on abortion,'' Mrs. Agee said. ``My mission is not a political one but a practical one.''

DOC.HEAD: Delta Reports `Disappointing' Earnings For Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines announced record earnings for calendar 1989 even though a sharp rise in fuel prices helped depress earnings by 25 percent in the last three months of the year. Delta Chairman Ronald W. Allen said Saturday that the profits dip in the October-Decmeber quarter also reflected weak passenger mile yields for Thanksgiving and Christmas, usually two of the busiest times for the airline. For the three months ended Dec. 31, the carrier's fiscal second quarter, Delta's net income was $64.2 million or $1.13 a share, down from $85.2 million or $1.73 a share a year earlier. Net income for calendar 1989 was $473.2 million or $9.23 a share, up 37 percent from $344.5 million or $7.03 a share in 1988. Operating revenue in the latest quarter rose to $2.04 billion from $1.9 billion a year earlier. But fuel costs rose to $314.2 million in the quarter from $220.5 million. Major U.S. airlines have cited higher fuel costs as the reason for fare hikes announced this month. ``We are very pleased with the record earnings for calendar 1989 but are disappointed with the lower earnings in the December quarter,'' Allen said. ``Fuel expenses rose 43 percent, the result of a 34 percent jump in the average price of aircraft fuel.'' Allen said passenger mile yields _ the money taken in per passenger for each mile flown _ fell about 1 percent during the holiday season to 13.39 cents from 13.48 cents a year earlier. Delta made numerous strides in 1989, Allen said. He said they included a 15 percent increase in traffic growth, a 5 percent increase in capacity growth, the addition of seven new domestic cities and two internationally in the route system and maintaining a young age for its fleet of aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Remains Firm, Stock Prices Gain Moderately in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar remained firm in early trading against the Japanese yen Monday while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange gained moderately. The dollar started trading at 146.35 yen, up 0.02 yen from last Friday's close of 146.33 yen. ``The yen is a currency that many investors will avoid buying this week'' ahead of the expected dissolution of Japan's lower house of parliament, a currency dealer with the Bank of Tokyo said. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is expected to dissolve the 512-member House of Representatives Wednesday, with balloting set for Feb. 18, local news media said. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 107.08 points last Friday, added another 101.39 points, or 0.27 percent, shortly after the market opened to stand at 36,937.93.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Contract Reached
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for USAir and more than 6,000 pilots have reached a tentative contract agreement following 27 hours of talks. The proposed settlement still must be approved by the Airline Pilots Association's master executive council, scheduled to meet Thursday. Chris Beebe, the council's vice chairman, said the panel can ratify the contract, return it to negotiators for further consideration or send it to the membership for ratification. The agreement was reached Friday in Miami. ``It's been a very, very long drawn-out process,'' Beebe said. ``With this much time and effort invested, to do anything hastily would be a mistake.'' The pilots have been working under terms of a contract that was open for amendment on Aug. 31, 1989. It is the longest USAir pilots have worked without a new pact. Neither Beebe nor USAir spokesman John Bronson would release terms of the proposal. The lack of a contract had hampered USAir from completing its merger with Piedmont Airlines. From August through December, former Piedmont pilots flew only aircraft from that airline and USAir pilots used only pre-merger USAir equipment. A transition agreement allowing crews to use planes from either airline took effect Jan. 1. USAir, meanwhile, remains locked in a dispute with the Teamsters, which is trying to organize some 8,000 baggage handlers and ramp workers in the merged airline. The National Mediation Board will count election ballots Jan. 30.
